A '''mortal wound''' is an injury that will ultimately lead to a person's death.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Easier English intermediate dictionary.|date=2004|publisher=Bloomsbury|isbn=9781408101995|edition=2nd|location=London|oclc=191801970}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.grammarphobia.com/blog/2017/02/fatal-mortal.html|title=Fatal or mortal?|date=2017-02-22|work=Grammarphobia|access-date=2018-10-12|language=en-US}}</ref> [[wiktionary:mortal|Mortal]] refers to the mortality of a human: whether they are going to live or die.<ref name=":0">"mortal_adjective." [[Oxford Advanced Learner's Dictionary]]. 2018. [[Oxford University Press]]. Accessed 14 September 2018. www.oxfordlearnersdictionaries.com.
https://www.oxfordlearnersdictionaries.com/definition/english/mortal_1?q=mortal</ref> [[Wiktionary:wound| Wound]] is another term for injury. The expression can mean 'extreme',<ref name=":0" /> for example when it was used in the 2017 Times article ''Being Frightened is not a Moral Wound.''<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.timescolonist.com/opinion/letters/being-frightened-is-not-a-mortal-wound-1.23086162|title=Being frightened is not a mortal wound|work=Times Colonist|access-date=2018-09-14}}</ref> The ''mortal wound'' adjectival phrase has the same meaning as the adverbial usage of ''mortally wounded'', ''mortally'' being the adverb of ''mortal'' and ''wounded'' being the adjective of ''wound''.
== Etymology == The adjective ''mortal'' was first used in the 14th Century. The word has roots in [[Old French]] ''mortel'' and [[Latin]] ''mortalis'' both meaning "fated to die" as well as ''mors'' meaning "in danger of death".<ref name=":1" /><ref>"mortal" [[Online Etymology Dictionary]]. 2018. Douglas Harper. [https://www.etymonline.com/ www.etymonline.com]. Accessed 12 September 2018. https://www.etymonline.com/word/mortal#etymonline_v_18381 </ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite book|title=A comprehensive etymological dictionary of the English language : dealing with the origin of words and their sense development thus illustrating the history of civilization and culture|last=1899-1983.|first=Klein, Ernest,|date=1971|publisher=Elsevier Pub. Co|isbn=978-0585483337|edition=Unabridged, one vol.|location=Amsterdam|oclc=53964772}}</ref>
The noun ''wound'' comes from [[Old English]] ''wund'' meaning "to injure" as well as the [[Proto-Germanic language|Proto-Germanic]] *''wuntho'' which also means "wound".<ref>"wound" [[Online Etymology Dictionary]]. 2018. Douglas Harper. [https://www.etymonline.com/ www.etymonline.com]. Accessed 12 September 2018.https://www.etymonline.com/word/wound#etymonline_v_10862 </ref><ref name=":3" />
== Early usage == [[File:Lannes mortally wounded at Essling (E. Boutigny).jpg|thumb|[[Jean Lannes|Marshal Jean Lannes]], mortally wounded at the [[battle of Essling]] in 1809, his left leg was amputated (right on picture) and he died a few days later.|alt=]] The first entry in the [[Oxford English Dictionary]] for ''mortal wound'' is dated 1578<ref name=":4">"skin. v" [[Oxford English Dictionary|OED Online]]. Draft Revision, September 2009. [[Oxford University Press]]. [http://www.oed.com/view/Entry/180923# OED.com] Accessed 12 October 2018. https://public.oed.com/updates/new-words-list-september-2009/</ref> and the first entry for ''mortally wounded'' is dated 1569.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://www.oed.com/view/Entry/122444|title=mortally, adv.|last=|first=|date=|website=OED Online, Oxford University Press|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-12}}</ref> Pre-1569, in the 1390 ''[[The Tale of Melibee|Melibeus]]'' by [[Geoffrey Chaucer]], the author uses the term "mortal woundes" in the quote "Thre of his olde foos..betten his wif wounded his doghter with fyue mortal woundes", this is where Melibeus's daughter received five mortal wounds, when three of his foes found Melibeus's wife and daughter alone in his house.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Canterbury Tales: The Tale of Melibeus|last=Chaucer|first=Geoffrey|publisher=|year=1387|isbn=|location=England|pages=2|url=https://www.bartleby.com/258/19.html}}</ref>
=== 1500s === In 1569, ''mortally wounded'' was used in the text ''Certaine Secrete Wonders Nature'' by [[wikisource:Fenton,_Edward_(d.1603)_(DNB00)|Edward Fenton]] in "aboue 400 dead bodies, beside 140 mortally wounded and almost torne in peces",<ref>{{Cite book|title=Certaine secrete wonders of nature, containing a descriptiõ of sundry strange things, seming monstrous in our eyes and iudgement, bicause we are not priuie to the reasons of them. Gathered out of diuers learned authors as well Greeke as Latine, sacred as prophane|last=Boaistuau|first=Pierre|publisher=Imprinted by H. Bynnemann|year=1569|isbn=|location=London|pages=20|translator-last=Fenton|translator-first=Edward|url=https://archive.org/details/b30320793/}}</ref> the quote explains that due to the extreme heat of a fire 140 men are wounded, the account said that they looked like they had been torn to pieces.
In 1578, ''mortal wound'' was used in the poetic text "''Courtlie Controuersie of Cupids Caulels "'' by [[Jacques Yver]] translated by Henry Wotton in "His mortal wound, that no long before was almost cured y a fomentation of the oyle of time, and neare skinned with hope of the recouerie of his welbeloued Iewel," the author describes how the personas old ''mortal wound'' was not yet recovered and as it was a serious wound, yet he hoped he would recover completely.<ref name=":4" />
In 1581, ''mortal wound'' was used in the historical non-fiction ''History of the Reformation of the Church of England'' by Gilbert Burnet and Nicholas Sander in “He went to ''Rome''; and giving the Assault, in which received his mortal wound” where''Vaudemont'' went to subdue the battle but was prevented by the Duke of ''Boubon'' receiving a ''mortal wound'', the Duke of ''Boubon'' then proceeded with the battle in ''Rome'' causing many deaths as well as leading The Pope with a few Cardinals to flee for safety.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.au/?id=gzRWAAAAYAAJ&q=%22mortal+wound%22|title=History of the Reformation of the Church of England: In two parts, Volume 1|last=Burnet|first=Gilbert|last2=Sander|first2=Nicholas|publisher=Thomas Hodgkin|year=1581|isbn=|location=Rose and Crown in St. Paul’s Church-yard|pages=6}}</ref>
In 1593, ''mortal wound'' was used in the sonnet ''Fidessa, More Chaste than Kind: Sonnet XXVII'' in “Yet every foot gives thee thy mortal wound” the quote comes from the Sonnet that describes a man stumbling in the street at night as he metaphorically compares his existence to that of a worm and due to the habitat of worms every step a person takes could be a ''mortal'' wound inflicted on worm ultimately leading to its death. In the Sonnet, the man believes that his existence is worse than that of a worm.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Fidessa, More Chaste than Kind|last=Griffin|first=Bartholomew|work=A English Garner: Elizabethan sonnets Vol II|publisher=Widow Orwin|year=1596|isbn=|location=London|pages=261-296: 285}}</ref>
=== 1600s === In 1661 ''mortal wound'' is used in the religious text ''The Unsearchable Riches of Christ'' where "The Lord Jesus hath given such a mortal wound by his death and Spirit" the text explains that because Jesus sacrificed himself and received his ''mortal wound'' in the [[New Testament]] because he did not die straight away but died "little by little" allowed him to rid the whole world of sin.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.au/?id=nGpjAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA43#v=onepage&q=%22mortal%20wound%22&f=false|title=The Unsearchable Riches of Christ: The third edition corrected and amended|last=Brooks|first=Thomas|publisher=Thomas Ward and Co.|year=1661|isbn=|location=London|pages=43}}</ref>
In 1667 ''mortal wound'' is used in [[John Milton]]'s ''[[wikisource:Paradise_Lost_(1667)/Book_VI|Paradise Lost VI]].'' In his epic biblical poem based on the retelling of [[Genesis creation narrative|Genesis]] he uses the term ''mortal wound'' in the passage "cannot but by annihilating die; Nor in their liquid texture mortal wound Receive, no more than can the fluid air," Milton explains spirits cannot receive ''mortal wounds'' due to the nature of their intangible form.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Paradise Lost IV|last=Milton|first=John|publisher=Samuel Simmons|year=1667|isbn=|location=England|pages=348|url=https://archive.org/details/selectionsfromp00walkgoog/}}</ref>
In 1672 the term ''mortal wound'' is used in the medical text ''The Chirurgical and Anatomical Works of Paul Barbette'', the text defines ''mortal wound'' as "A mortal Wound is that, which in the Space of few hours, or dayes, of necessity causes Death, and cannot by any Artt be Cured." The text further goes on to explain that if a wound is curable but has been neglected by the patient and results in death that it is not considered a ''mortal wound'' even though it resulted in the patients death. This also applies to wounds that are incurable and allow the patient to live for weeks to years. Therefore, the author explains that if the wound does not result in a "sudden" death it is not considered a "mortal wound."<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.au/?id=ysZjAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA148#v=onepage&q=%22mortal%20wound%22&f=false|title=The Chirurgical and Anatomical Works of Paul Barbette, M.D. Practitioner at Amsterdam.|last=Barbette|first=Paul|publisher=J. Darby|year=1672|isbn=|location=London|pages=148}}</ref>
===1700s=== The ''[[The London Gazette|London Gazette]]'' is one of the British governments official journals. In the 1714 ''The [[The London Gazette|London Gazette]]: Issue 5228,'' under the ''Advertisements'' section, ''mortal wound'' is used to describe an injury a man named Edward Hurley received from a [[Twybil|Two-Bill]] from the quote "Whereas one Henry Bray, Weaver, now or late of Culmstock, in the County of Devon, did on Tuesday the 18<sup>th</sup> Instant, give one Edward Hurley … a mortal Wound on the Head with a Two-Bill, that he dy’d.” the journal goes on to describe Henry Bray's appearance, mannerisms and the clothes he usually wears as well as stating that anyone that helps bring him to justice will receive a monetary reward.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=12 October 2018|title=The London Gazette|url=https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/5228/page/2/data.htm|journal=The London Gazette|publication-date=25 May 1714|volume=|issue=5228|pages=2|via=The Gazette Official Public Record}}</ref>
The first dictionary that had an entry for ''mortal wound'' is Edward Phillips's ''[[The New World of English Words|The New World of Words]]: or, Universal English Dictionary,'' ''16th edition,'' published in 1720. The entry says "Mortal Wound. See ''Wound''"<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=tp4NAAAAQAAJ&printsec=frontcover|title=The New World of Words: or, Universal English Dictionary, 16th edition|last=Phillips|first=Edward|publisher=John Kersey|year=1720|isbn=|location=|pages=443}}</ref> at the entry for wound the definition for mortal wound states "Mortal Wound, is that which must unavoidably be follow'd by Death, when it is situate deep in a principal Part, necessary for the Preservation of Life: Such are wounds in the Heart, Lungs, Midriff, Liver, Spleen Etc. and generally in all the great Vessels".<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=tp4NAAAAQAAJ&printsec=frontcover|title=The New World of Words: or, Universal English Dictionary, 16th edition|last=Phillips|first=Edward|publisher=John Kersey|year=1720|isbn=|location=|pages=711}}</ref>
Poet [[Allan Ramsay (poet)|Allan Ramsay]], during 1724, in ''[[wikisource:Ramsay,_Allan_(1686-1758)_(DNB00)|Health]]: a poem 1st edition'' described “When th’ uvula has got its mortal wound, and tongue and lips form words without a sound;" where he states that the uvula had received a ''mortal wound'', using the term metaphorically to describe an uvula infection possibly due to Influenza which often lead to death in the 1700s.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gold|first=Eli|date=1987-05-15|title=Pandemic Influenza 1700-1900: A Study in Historical Epidemiology|url=https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/article-abstract/366172|journal=JAMA: The Journal of the American Medical Association|language=en|volume=257|issue=19|pages=2656|doi=10.1001/jama.1987.03390190134045|issn=0098-7484}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=nnc1.0038496801;view=1up;seq=11|title=The Poems of Allan Ramsay, Volume 1|last=Ramsay|first=Allan|publisher=A. Strahan|year=1800|isbn=|location=London|pages=92}}</ref>
In 1760 ''mortal wound'' is used in the Trial of ''Lawrence Earl Ferrers, for the Murder of John Johnson''. John Johnson received "One mortal Wound of the ‘Breadth of One Inch and Depth of Four Inches; of which said moral Wound the said ''John Johnson'' did ... live, until the Nineteenth Day of the same Month of January, ... on which Day, ... he the said John Johnson, of the mortal Wound aforesaid, died." During the trial the Juror's found ''Lawrence Earl Ferrers'' guilty for murder as he purposefully and without remorse injured ''John Johnson'' which lead to his death.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.au/?id=pXQ0AQAAMAAJ&pg=RA4-PA6#v=onepage&q=%22mortal%20wound%22&f=false|title=The Trial of Lawrence Earl Ferrers, for the Murder of John Johnson, Before the Right Honourable: The House of Peers, in Westminster-Hall, in Full Parliament.|last=|first=|work=Trials|publisher=Order of the house of PEERS|year=1760|isbn=|location=London: Chancery lane|pages=205: 4}}</ref>
Other examples of "mortal wound" are found inside:
*The 1725 written account of ''[[c:File:A_true_and_genuine_account_of_the_last_confession_and_dying_words_of_John_Gow,_alias_Smith,_captain_of_the_pirates_Fleuron_T113005-2.png|The Last confession and Dying Words]] of [[John Gow]],''<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=CT9fAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA10|title=A True and Genuine Account of the Last Confession and Dying Words of John Gow, alias Smith, Captain of the Pirates, as likewise of the Eight Others, who were executed with him.|last=Gow|first=John|publisher=|year=1725|isbn=|location=London|pages=10,15}}</ref> *The 1767 non-fiction text ''A Practical Treatise on Wounds and Other Chirurgical Subjects'' by Benjamin Gooch,<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=RbfBe-JhzmAC&pg=PA110&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=mortal%20wound&f=false|title=A Practical Treatise on Wounds and Other Chirurgical Subjects|last=Gooch|first=Benjamin|publisher=W. Chase|year=1767|isbn=|location=Norwich|pages=116, 218}}</ref>
=== 1800s === In the 1817 love poem ''[[The Revolt of Islam|Laon and Cythna]]'' by Percy Bysshe Shelley used ''mortal wound'' to describe "Upon his enemies heart a mortal wound to wreck," where a metaphorical eagle wished to give his enemy: a serpent, a mortal wound.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.online-literature.com/shelley_percy/2779/|title=Laon and Cythna; or, The Revolution of the Golden City: A Vision of the Nineteenth Century|last=Shelley|first=Percy Bysshe|publisher=|year=1817|isbn=|location=London|pages=10}}</ref>
The 1838 romance novel ''[[Leila; or, The Siege of Granada|Leila]]'' ''II. ii. by'' [[Edward Bulwer-Lytton]] uses ''mortal wound'' to depict the scene "while the blood oozes slow and gurgling from a mortal wound," this line occurs when a soldier wearing armour did not appear to have been wounded but blood was leaking from a serious wound he had sustained.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/9757/pg9757-images.html|title=Leila or, The Siege of Granada II|last=Lytton|first=Edward Bulwer|publisher=A. Asher|year=1838|isbn=|location=Berlin|pages=Chapter 2: 44}}</ref>
The 1865 text ''Camps and Prisons. Twenty Months in the Department of the Gulf'' by [[Augustine Joseph Hickey Duganne]] is a collection of personal accounts of the civil war. ''Mortal wound'' is used by the author when he exclaims "And the wide land with mortal wound outbleeds!" the author is describing the mass of men that are found with seriously injured throughout the land he stands on.<ref>{{Cite book|url=//archive.org/details/campsprisonstwen00dugarich/page/344|title=Camps and prisons : twenty months in the Department of the Gulf|last=Duganne|first=Augustine Joseph Hickey|publisher=J. P. Robens|year=1865|isbn=|location=New York|pages=344}}</ref>
=== 1900s === In the 1982 non-fiction ''Tortious Liability for Unintentional Harm in the Common Law and the Civil Law,'' the author discusses problems associated with liability in European Law. He uses the term ''mortal wound'' to discuss the issue of accountability regarding ''mortally wounding'' a slave. The author states "In the first, Celsus, Marcellus and Ulpian agree that if one man gives a slave a moral wound and another afterwards kills him, only the latter is liable under the first chapter for killing the former only under the third for wounding," while contrastingly he also explains "Julian… says... if one man gives a slave a mortal wound and after an interval another strikes him in a way as to hasten his death, both are liable for killing." The author explains that the juxtaposition is due to Julian focusing on the original wound being intentionally mortal, leading to the slaves death, while Celsus contradicts Julian and mainly focuses on the importance of the resulting death of the slave.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.au/?id=huc7AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA31#v=onepage&q=mortal%20wound&f=false|title=Tortious Liability for Unintentional Harm in the Common Law and the Civil Law: Volume 1, Text|last=Lawson|first=F. H.|last2=Markesinis|first2=B. S.|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1982|isbn=|location=Great Britain: Cambridge|pages=31}}</ref>
The religious text ''The Apocalypse: A Reading of the Revelation of John'' published in 1994 uses the term ''moral wound'' in reference to ''Revelation 13:3,'' the text describes a beast where “one of its heads seemed to have a mortal wound, but its wound was healed,” The author explains that this section of ''Revelation 13'' refers to the legend of [[Nero]], Roman Emperor, ‘coming back to life’ or still being alive after receiving a ''mortal wound'' and his vengeful goal of leading the Parthian army to the destroy Rome.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=UldIEV_aKoQC&dq|title=The Apocalypse: A Reading of the Revelation of John|last=Talbert|first=Charles H.|publisher=Westminster John Knox Press|year=1994|isbn=|location=Louisville, Kentucky|pages=52}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://amazingdiscoveries.org/S-deception_beasts_wound_Mussolini_Napoleon|title=The First Beast's Wound|last=Professor Walter J. Veith, PhD|first=|date=May 26, 2009|website=amazingdiscoveries.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref>
In the 1997 text ''Virgil's [[Aeneid]]: Semantic Relations and Proper Names'' the author reflects on Virgil's epic poem using ''mortal wound'' in "The mortal wound that Turnus inflicted on the youth made this wound an unhealable one." this is where Turnus and Aeneas are battling in Italy, even though Aeneas is injured he returns to battle and "Aeneas inflicts the mortal wound on Turnus in the name of ‘Pallas’." where Aeneas takes vengence for Turnus killing his friend Pallas.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=o5-3qxjL6lgC&hl=en|title=Virgil's Aeneid: Semantic Relations and Proper Names|last=Paschalis|first=Michael|publisher=Clarendon Press: Oxford|year=1997|isbn=|location=New York|pages=12}}</ref>
Other examples of "mortal wound" are found inside:
* The 1964 novel ''The Mortal Wound'' by Raffaele La Capria about a man's connection with Naples during his travels to Rome,<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/mortalwound00laca|title=The Mortal Wound|last=La Capria|first=Raffaele|publisher=Farrar & Straus|year=1964|isbn=|location=New York|pages=}}</ref> * The 1968 novel ''[[King, Queen, Knave]]'' by [[Vladimir Nabokov]] "he threatened her with a priapus that had already once inflicted upon her an almost mortal wound,"<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/stream/in.ernet.dli.2015.45367/2015.45367.King-Queen-Knave_djvu.txt|title=King, Queen, Knave|last=Nabokov|first=Vladimir|publisher=McGraw-Hill|year=1968|isbn=|location=US|pages=177|translator-last=Nabokov|translator-first=Dmitri}}</ref>
== Modern usage ==
The number of [[Google]] search hits on 12 August 2006 for "mortally wounded" was 989,000 <ref>{{Cite book|title=Cognitive linguistic approaches to teaching vocabulary and phraseology|last=|first=|date=2008|publisher=Mouton de Gruyter|others=Boers, Frank., Lindstromberg, Seth, 1949-|isbn=9783110199161|location=Berlin|pages=337|oclc=560639481}}</ref> The number of Google hits on 12 October 2018 for "mortal wound" had 346,000 results and "mortally wounded" had 1,660,000 results.
More modern usage of the term ''mortal wound'' is often more figurative than literal: seen in the 1998 article ''Paternal Style Leaves Mortal Wounds'' by Deutsch Stephen. The article talks about the demise of a hospital without a director present and a proper mission statement which would lead to it's implied 'eventual' death.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Deutsch|first=S. I.|date=1998|title=Paternal style leaves mortal wounds.|url=http://ezproxy.library.usyd.edu.au/login?url=https://search-proquest-com.ezproxy1.library.usyd.edu.au/docview/204309892?accountid=14757|journal=Government Executive|volume=30|issue=3|pages=33|via=ProQuest}}</ref>
=== Usage in law === ''The Law Dictionary (2013)'' defines the term mortal wound as "the term that is applied to a wound that is fatal"<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thelawdictionary.org/mortal-wound/|title=What is MORTAL WOUND? definition of MORTAL WOUND (Black's Law Dictionary)|date=2013-03-28|work=The Law Dictionary|access-date=2018-10-12|language=en-US}}</ref>
In the 2007 ''Republic of Philippines Supreme Court Petition for Review'' of Lazaro (petitioner) versus Crisaldo Alberto (prosecutor) the decision report uses the term "mortal wound", it discusses the importance of being able to discern whether the petitioner had inflicted a mortal or non-mortal wound on the prosecutor Crisaldo in determining the sentence for Lazaro. If the Jury believed that Crisaldo had been inflicted with a mortal wound, which would have lead to death if untreated, then Lazaro would be accused of attempted murder, rather than frustrated murder. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sc.judiciary.gov.ph/jurisprudence/2007/june2007/157057.htm|title=Lazaro v. Alberto, Petition for Review 2007|last=|first=|date=|website=Republic of Philippines, Supreme Court|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-12}}</ref>
According to ''Causation in Criminal Law'' from the Pennsylvania Law Review the term "moral wound" is used to denote that an injury is serious.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Midson|first=Brenda|date=2010|title=Teaching Causation in Criminal Law: Learning to Think Like Policy Analysts|url=http://classic.austlii.edu.au/au/journals/LegEdRev/2010/7.html|journal=Legal Education Review|volume=20(1&2)|pages=109|via=}}</ref> In ''Causation in the Law'' from Oxford University Press, the term "mortal wound" is given three meanings: (i) an injury that is likely to cause death to an average person under normal circumstances (ii) an injury that has a high likelihood of causing the victim death if left untreated medically; (iii) an injury that is likely to cause death even though it does not apply to the first two circumstances (e.g. a minor injury neglected by the victim).<ref name=":6" />
=== Usage in the media === The 2018 Australian news article ''Dutton delivers mortal wound to Turnbull'' uses "mortal wound" metaphorically as the death of Prime minister Turnbull's party's support. Member of parliament Petter Dutton challenged Prime minister Malcolm Turnbull for leadership of the Australian Liberal Party. The article describes it as, when fewer than 60% of a prime minister's colleagues support him he is a "dead leader walking."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.msn.com/en-au/news/australia/dutton-delivers-mortal-wound-to-turnbull/ar-BBMc0hp|title=Dutton delivers mortal wound to Turnbull|website=www.msn.com|language=en-AU|access-date=2018-09-14}}</ref>
''Being Frightened is not a Mortal Wound'' is a 2017 article written by the Times Columnist as a response to a letter on the 2nd November, ''Let’s rethink Halloween Fireworks.'' The letter describes its dissatisfaction that people believe that taking offence is synonymous with being ''mortally wounded''. They use this stance to argue that people are being overly cautious by trying to alter the halloween fireworks due to the possibility of frightening animals and children.<ref name=":2" />
== References == {{reflist}}
== Further reading == *[https://www.bartleby.com/258/19.html ''The Tale of Melibeus (Melibee)'' in medieval english] *[https://sites.fas.harvard.edu/~chaucer/teachslf/mel-tran.htm ''The Tale of Melibeus (Melibee)'' in modern english] *''[[iarchive:b30320793/page/n31|Certaine Secrete Wonders of Nature]]'' *[https://books.google.com.au/books?id=4kbxCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA63&lpg=PA63&dq=mortal+wound+Laon+and+Cythna&source=bl&ots=lp9q2OruRe&sig=vq6FbGhspOFunqoHc-PwEFyjq-g&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjI_ISYupLeAhXEdn0KHdpSBGQQ6AEwA3oECAcQAQ#v=onepage&q=mortal%20wound%20Laon%20 ''Laon and Cythna'' by Percy Bysshe Shelly] *''[https://books.google.com.au/books?id=jg8mAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA54&lpg=PA54&dq=Leila+II.+ii.+by+Edward+Bulwer-Lytton+mortal+wound&source=bl&ots=5_7wamJfHU&sig=lOrnfLH67GhktSpic29NDZKQ6EE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiN3vbTu5LeAhVXTn0KHROyBbEQ6AEwA3oECAkQAQ#v=onepage&q=Leila%20II.%20ii.%20by%20Edward%20Bulwer-Lytton%20mortal%20wound&f=false Leila: Or, The Siege of Grenada]'' by Edward Bulwer-Lytton *[[iarchive:campsprisonstwen00dugarich|''Camps and Prisons: 20 Months in the Department'' of the Gulf]] by Duganne *[https://onlinebooks.library.upenn.edu/webbin/gutbook/author?name=Lytton%2C%20Edward%20Bulwer%20Lytton%2C%20Baron%2C%201803%2D1873 Project Gutenberg Titles]: a large collection of books by Edward Bulwer-Lytton that have been made available online. *[https://archive.org/stream/in.ernet.dli.2015.45367/2015.45367.King-Queen-Knave_djvu.txt King, Queen, Knave] by Nabokov *{{IMDb title|tt6705510}}

| image5 = | candidate5 = | 1data5 = | 2data5 = | 3data5 = | 4data5 = | colour5 =
| title = Leader | before_election = [[Theresa May]] | after_election = }}--> [[File:Theresa May Tallinn Digital (Crop).jpg|thumb|Party leader and Prime Minister [[Theresa May]] in late 2017]] The '''next Conservative Party leadership election''' has not yet been formally launched. Speculation of a leadership election centres around the [[Leader of the Conservative Party (UK)|Leader of the Conservative Party]] and [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] [[Theresa May]]'s fate. It first arose following the party's poor showing at the [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|2017 snap general election]] that May had called in hope of increasing her parliamentary majority for Brexit negotiations. However, the Conservatives lost their majority in the House of Commons due to a swing towards the Labour Party.
Subsequent speculation has arisen from the difficulties May has had in agreeing a [[Brexit]] deal that is acceptable to the Conservative Party. These escalated in November 2018, with members of the [[Eurosceptic]] [[European Research Group]] pushing for a vote of no confidence in May. Were this to occur and May to lose, a new leadership election would be called.
==Background== After [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|Britain voted to leave the EU]], [[David Cameron]] resigned as Leader of the Conservative Party and as Prime Minister, which triggered the [[Conservative Party (UK) leadership election, 2016|2016 Conservative Party leadership election]]. Home Secretary Theresa May won the contest after the withdrawal of [[Andrea Leadsom]], and succeeded Cameron as Prime Minister on 13 July. As Prime Minister, May began the process of [[Brexit|withdrawing the UK from the European Union]], triggering [[Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union|Article 50]] on 29 March 2017. In April 2017, May announced a snap [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|general election in June]], in order to "strengthen her hand" when she negotiated with the European Union. Opinion polls originally predicted a landslide victory for the Conservative Party, and May aimed to substantially increase her party's slim majority. However, the result was a hung parliament, in which the number of Conservative seats fell from 330 to 317, prompting her to broker a [[confidence and supply]] [[Conservative–DUP agreement|deal]] with Northern Ireland's [[Democratic Unionist Party]] (DUP) to support her minority government.
May's handling of the campaign was widely criticised, particularly the role of her two chiefs of staff, [[Nick Timothy]] and [[Fiona Hill]]. In June 2017, former Chancellor of the Exchequer, [[George Osborne]], described May as a "dead woman walking".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2017-40237819|title=General election 2017: Theresa May is 'best placed person' for Brexit|date=11 June 2017|publisher=|accessdate=9 September 2017|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> A survey on the website [[Conservative Home]] found that almost two-thirds of Conservative party members wanted Theresa May to resign.<ref name="telegraph">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/06/10/almost-two-thirds-conservative-party-members-want-theresa-may/|title= Almost two thirds of Conservative Party members want Theresa May to resign as Prime Minister|first=Jack|last= Maidment|website=telegraph.co.uk|date=10 June 2017|accessdate=10 June 2017}}</ref> A YouGov poll of 1,720 adults for the ''Sunday Times'' had 48% saying May should resign, with 38% against.<ref name="home.bt.com">{{cite web|url=http://home.bt.com/news/uk-news/48-think-theresa-may-should-step-down-as-prime-minister-poll-shows-11364187027615|title=48% think Theresa May should step down as Prime Minister, poll shows|website=home.bt.com|date=11 June 2017}}</ref> A Survation poll of 1,036 adults online for the ''Mail on Sunday'' showed 49% of people wanting her resignation, with 38% against.<ref name="home.bt.com" /> Former Cabinet minister [[Anna Soubry]] called for May to "consider her position" after the election result. Former Cabinet minister [[Nicky Morgan]] said that May could not lead the Conservative Party into the next general election and called for a leadership election in the summer or in 2018 before the Brexit deal is finalised. Brexiteers pledged loyalty to May but many reportedly threatened an immediate leadership challenge should May plan to dilute her initial plans for Brexit. After the [[Grenfell Tower fire]], May's leadership faced more criticism after her initial refusal to meet victims and her poor handling of the crisis.
With May's position weakened, senior colleagues in the party were said to be preparing for a leadership contest and "jostling for succession".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://amp.ft.com/content/02f15952-6099-11e7-8814-0ac7eb84e5f1|title=Theresa May braced for a fall as Brexit tests loom|website=amp.ft.com|accessdate=9 September 2017}}</ref> Politicians and journalists do not expect May to lead the party at the next general election, with the Sunday Times Political Editor [[Tim Shipman]] describing "the first shots in a battle that could tear the government apart" in a July 2017 article as the three then-leading contenders for the leadership, [[David Davis (British politician)|David Davis]], [[Boris Johnson]] and [[Philip Hammond]], briefed against each other.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/mr-grey-mr-blond-and-mr-brexit-battle-of-the-big-guns-sj0zs2pzz|title=Mr Grey, Mr Blond and Mr Brexit: battle of the big guns|first=Tim Shipman, Political|last=Editor|publisher=|accessdate=9 September 2017}}</ref> Junior ministers were also said to be frustrated at Cabinet ministers propping up a Prime Minister with no authority to further their careers, with some ministers preparing to resign in order to trigger a leadership election. [[Andrew Mitchell]], an ally of Davis, was said to have told a dinner that May was finished and was said to be organising letters to force May to announce her date of departure.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/jul/09/theresa-may-pressure-to-quit-former-ministers-andrew-mitchell-grant-shapps|title=May attempts to reassert grip over Tory party amid talk of challenge|first=Rowena Mason Deputy political|last=editor|date=9 July 2017|publisher=|accessdate=9 September 2017|via=The Guardian}}</ref> A July 2017 report in The Independent said a core of fifteen Conservative MPs were ready to sign a letter of no confidence, with forty-eight needed to trigger a contest.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/theresa-may-no-confidence-letter-tory-conservative-mps-jeremy-corbyn-a7855451.html|title=15 Tory MPs 'sign no confidence letter in Theresa May'|date=23 July 2017|publisher=|accessdate=9 September 2017}}</ref>
May reportedly announced to Conservative MPs in August 2017 that she would resign as Prime Minister on 30 August 2019, making it likely that the next leadership election would take place in the summer of 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2017/08/27/theresa-may-is-apparently-going-to-resign-in-2019-6881925/|title=Theresa May is apparently 'going to resign in 2019'|first=Adam|last=Smith|date=27 August 2017|publisher=|accessdate=9 September 2017}}</ref> However, May subsequently announced on 31 August 2017 that she intended to stay on to fight the next general election, which under the [[Fixed-term Parliaments Act 2011]] is scheduled to be in 2022 (though it can be held earlier if MPs vote for it to be, as happened for the snap election of 2017).<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.ft.com/content/182055d0-8d80-11e7-a352-e46f43c5825d|title=Theresa May vows to fight next UK election as prime minister|date=31 August 2017|accessdate=31 August 2017|newspaper=Financial Times|first=Robert|last=Wright}}</ref>
On 16 September 2017, Johnson published an article in ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' laying out his vision for Brexit. Many people saw this as him positioning himself for a leadership challenge,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://yougov.co.uk/opi/surveys/results#/survey/f239f61c-9c54-11e7-8370-e14fde485354/question/60e9d673-9c55-11e7-9df1-dfcb2e853687/toplines|title=YouGov - What the world thinks|website=yougov.co.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/theresa-may-cabinet-boris-johnson-brexit-manifesto-conservatives-tory-leader-prime-minister-a7953866.html|title=Theresa May just responded to Boris Johnson's '£350m claim' for the NHS|date=18 September 2017|publisher=}}</ref> although some commentators, such as ''[[Newsnight]]'''s political editor [[Nick Watt]] and columnist [[Iain Dale]], argued this was the wrong interpretation and that Johnson's motivation was to assert his influence in Brexit negotiations. The timing of the article, a few days before May was to give a significant speech on her plans for the UK's relationship with Europe after Brexit, and shortly after a terrorist attack in London, was criticised.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-41307263|title=May 'driving from the front' on Brexit|date=18 September 2017|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref><ref>''Newsnight'', BBC2, 18 September 2017</ref>
===2018=== Following Cabinet agreement for May's proposals on Brexit, Davis resigned from his government position on 8 July 2018.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Rayner |first1=Gordon |title=David Davis resigns as Brexit secretary |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2018/07/08/david-davis-resigns-brexit-secretary/ |accessdate=8 July 2018 |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=8 July 2018}}</ref><ref name="resignation">{{cite news |title=Brexit Secretary David Davis resigns |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-44761056 |work=BBC News |date=9 July 2018}}</ref> Following that, [[Steve Baker (politician)|Steve Baker]] also resigned. On the same day it was reported that May was facing the threat of a leadership contest amid mounting anger from Brexiteers over her government's Brexit policy.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/brexit-latest-theresa-may-leadership-challenge-plan-tories-mps-chequers-jacob-rees-mogg-a8437706.html|title=Theresa May faces leadership challenge threat from Tory Brexiteers|publisher=}}</ref> Conservative Party backbencher [[Andrea Jenkyns]] called on for the Prime Minister to be replaced, saying “Theresa May's premiership is over”.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2018/07/top-uk-brexit-officials-resign-in-blow-to-theresa-may.html|title=Top Brexit Officials Resign in Blow to Theresa May|first=Margaret|last=Hartmann|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/brexit/2018/0709/977344-brexit-british-government/|title=May to fight any leadership challenge|date=9 July 2018|publisher=}}</ref> Johnson later resigned as Foreign Secretary on 9 July 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/jul/09/boris-johnson-resigns-as-foreign-secretary-brexit|title=Boris Johnson resigns as foreign secretary over May's Brexit plans|last=|first=|date=|website=The Guardian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
A ''Daily Telegraph'' article opposing the [[burqa ban]] in Denmark by Johnson in early August 2018 sparked controversy given some of the language he used, saying women wearing the burqa look like letter boxes or bank robbers. Some saw it as an attempt to court an anti-Islamic segment of the Conservative Party membership,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/08/world/europe/boris-johnson-trump-burqa.html|title=Boris Johnson, a ‘Burqa Storm’ and Perhaps Some Populist Calculations|publisher=}}</ref> the electorate in a leadership campaign, while others defended him as straight-talking. [[Dominic Grieve]] MP said on 8 August that he would not remain in the party if Johnson became leader.<ref>''Newsnight'', BBC2, 8 August 2018</ref>
In November 2018, May presented her final proposal for an initial Brexit deal following negotiations with the EU. [[Dominic Raab]], her Brexit secretary, and others resigned from the Cabinet in response,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-46219495|title=Raab quits over 'flawed' Brexit agreement|date=15 November 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> with [[Jacob Rees-Mogg]] calling for a leadership election for the first time. Members of the [[Eurosceptic]] [[European Research Group]], like Rees-Mogg and [[Steve Baker (politician)|Steve Baker]], were seen to be launching a coup in mid-November following the Cabinet resignations. There was considerable speculation over whether enough letters of no confidence would be reached to trigger a vote.<ref name="auto">''Newsnight'', BBC2, 15 November 2018</ref>
15% of the Parliamentary party (currently 48 MPs) need to send a letter to the chairman of the [[1922 Committee]] to trigger a no confidence vote in the Conservative Party leader. As of early afternoon on 16 November 2018, the BBC reported there were 21 MPs who had publicly stated they had sent a letter: Rees-Mogg, Baker, [[Andrea Jenkyns]], [[Andrew Bridgen]], [[Philip Davies]], [[James Duddridge]], [[Anne Marie Morris]], [[Lawrence Robertson]], [[Nadine Dorries]], [[Simon Clarke (politician)|Simon Clarke]], [[Henry Smith (British politician)|Henry Smith]], [[Maria Caulfield]], [[Sheryll Murray]], [[Lee Rowley]], [[Martin Vickers]], [[Peter Bone]], [[Mark Francois]], [[Adam Holloway]], [[John Whittingdale]], [[Ben Bradley (politician)|Ben Bradley]], [[Chris Green (politician)|Chris Green]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-46237174|title=Who has written no confidence letters?|date=17 November 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> Baker asserted that more letters had been sent and that he expected 48 to be reached probably in the week beginning 19 November.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/uk-politics-46200010|title=May bids to shore up support for Brexit deal|publisher=}}</ref> However, commentators expressed some scepticism about this prediction.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/opinion/brexit-plotters-give-us-a-lesson-on-how-not-to-do-a-coup|title=Brexit plotters give us a lesson on how not to do a coup|date=16 November 2018|publisher=}}</ref> By 19 November, 26 MPs publicly said they had submitted letters, with the addition of [[Marcus Fysh]], [[Zac Goldsmith]], [[David Jones (Clwyd West MP)|David Jones]], [[Bill Cash]], and [[Philip Hollobone]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-46237174|title=Who has written no confidence letters?|date=19 November 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> Baker also suggested that the ERG could draw lots for who would be their candidate in a leadership election.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/nov/16/may-the-force-be-with-her-theresa-pm-digs-in-with-her-brexit-deal|title=May the force be with her? The PM digs in with her Brexit deal|first=Heather|last=Stewart|date=16 November 2018|website=the Guardian}}</ref> By 20 November, the 48 letters had not been reached, with Rees-Mogg predicting that it may be reached in December when the House of Commons votes on May's deal.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-46269757|title=Don't get stuck with May, Rees-Mogg warns|date=20 November 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
==Candidates== A very large number of candidates have attracted attention or been the subject of speculation as possible candidates. In 2017, the main contenders were initially seen to be Philip Hammond, David Davis, Boris Johnson and [[Amber Rudd]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/theresa-may-leadership-challenge-conservative-tory-leadership-election-2017-a7784226.html|title=Main candidates to replace Theresa May would all make Tories less popular, poll suggests|date=11 June 2017|publisher=|accessdate=9 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/06/09/could-replace-theresa-may-tory-leader-runners-riders-latest/|title=Who could replace Theresa May as Tory leader? The runners and riders - and latest odds|publisher=|accessdate=9 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/general-election-2017-list-likely-conservative-party-to-take-over-theresa-may-as-prime-minister-2017-6|title=The 5 Conservative politicians most likely to replace Theresa May as Tory leader|publisher=|accessdate=9 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/jul/22/david-davis-theresa-may-conservative-leadership|title=Tory members turn to David Davis in battle to succeed Theresa May|first=Michael|last=Savage|date=22 July 2017|publisher=|accessdate=9 September 2017|via=The Guardian}}</ref> By early August 2017, [[Jacob Rees-Mogg]] was receiving considerable attention and he had risen to second in the betting markets after Davis.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/comment/comment/look-beyond-jacob-reesmogg-s-cartoony-shtick-at-what-he-really-stands-for-a3611141.html|title=Look beyond Jacob Rees-Mogg’s cartoony shtick at what he really stands for|publisher=|accessdate=9 September 2017}}</ref>
[[Ruth Davidson]] has continuously received considerable speculation, despite being ineligible as she is not currently an MP at Westminster.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-07-18/britain-s-next-conservative-leader-may-be-the-least-tory-ever|title=Bloomberg - Are you a robot?|website=www.bloomberg.com}}</ref><ref name=week /> However, she claimed that she did not want the job and would focus on politics in Scotland in September 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.sky.com/story/ruth-davidson-rules-out-becoming-next-conservative-leader-for-sake-of-relationship-11499429|title=Ruth Davidson rules out becoming next Conservative leader for sake of relationship|work=Sky News|access-date=2018-09-15|language=en-GB}}</ref>
Following renewed speculation about May's leadership after Johnson and Davis resigned from the Cabinet in summer 2018, press interest focused on Johnson, Rees-Mogg, [[Michael Gove]], [[Sajid Javid]] and [[Jeremy Hunt]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/jun/30/sajid-javid-is-surprise-choice-of-tory-activists-to-be-next-party-leader|title=Sajid Javid is Tory activists' choice to be next party leader – poll|first=Lin|last=Jenkins|date=30 June 2018|website=the Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/boris-johnson-conservative-leader-theresa-may-brexit-cabinet-tory-poll-members-a8472341.html|title=Boris Johnson emerges as favourite to replace Theresa May after dramatic cabinet resignation|publisher=}}</ref><ref name=week>{{cite web|url=http://www.theweek.co.uk/94917/tory-leader-race-who-would-be-in-the-running|title=Tory leader race: who would be in the running?|publisher=}}</ref> [[Dominic Raab]] became Brexit secretary after Davis. In November 2018, following his resignation from the role, Raab became the bookmakers' favourite to be new leader,<ref name="auto"/> followed by Javid<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/politics/next-tory-leader-odds-who-13593904|title=Odds on who will replace Theresa May as Conservative leader|first=Daisy|last=Naylor|date=15 November 2018|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://metro.co.uk/2018/11/15/dominc-raab-favourite-to-be-next-conservative-leader-but-jeremy-corbyn-backed-to-be-next-prime-minister-8143074/|title=Dominic Raab leads next Tory leader odds but Corbyn favourite for next PM|date=15 November 2018|publisher=}}</ref> or Johnson.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/11/15/runners-riders-latest-odds-candidates-could-become-next-pm/|title=Runners and riders: the latest odds on the candidates who could become the next PM|first=Camilla|last=Tominey|date=15 November 2018|publisher=|via=www.telegraph.co.uk}}</ref>

===Potential=== As of {{currentmonth}} {{currentyear}}, the following individuals have received speculation as potential leadership candidates. * [[Bim Afolami]], Member of Parliament for [[Hitchin and Harpenden]] since 2017 (Remain supporter)<ref>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-45785004</ref> * [[Victoria Atkins]], [[Home Office|Parliamentary Undersecretary of State for Crime, Safeguarding and Vulnerability]] since 2017 (Remain supporter)<ref>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-45785004</ref> * [[Kemi Badenoch]], Member of Parliament for [[Saffron Walden]] since 2017 (Leave supporter)<ref>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-45785004</ref> * [[Steve Baker (politician)|Steve Baker]], [[Department for Exiting the European Union|Parliamentary Undersecretary of State for Exiting the European Union]] from 2017 to 2018 (Leave supporter)<ref name="thetimes1">{{cite web|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/boris-fears-losing-no-10-to-young-rival-cnlrljzkr|title=Boris fears losing No 10 to young rival|first=Tim Shipman and Caroline|last=Wheeler|date=8 October
