{{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = Sanja Matsuri |type = shinto |image = View of mikoshi from sensoji Sanja Matsuri 2006-3.jpg |imagesize = 250px |caption = A view of the [[Hōzōmon]] as well as one of the main ''[[mikoshi]]'' as seen from the top of the steps of the [[Sensō-ji]] |official_name = |nickname = |observedby = Tokyo |litcolor = |longtype = Religious |significance = Honors [[Hinokuma Hamanari]], [[Hinokuma Takenari]] and [[Hajino Nakatomo]], the three founders of [[Sensō-ji]] |begins = Friday |ends = Sunday |scheduling = nth weekday of the month |duration = 3 days |frequency = annual |date{{CURRENTYEAR}} = {{Weekday before date|{{CURRENTYEAR}}|May|{{Weekday in month|3|0|5}}|Friday}} |date{{NEXTYEAR}} = {{Weekday before date|{{NEXTYEAR}}|May|{{Weekday in month|3|0|5|next year}}|Friday}} }}
{{nihongo|'''Sanja Matsuri'''|三社祭||literally "Three Shrine Festival"}}, or '''Sanja Festival''', is one of the three great [[Shinto]] [[festivals in Tokyo]]. It is considered one of the wildest and largest.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hoteltravel.com/japan/guides/festivals.htm#sanja_matsuri |title=Japan Events and Festivals |accessdate=2008-05-07 |work=HotelTravel.com}}</ref> The festival is held in honor of Hinokuma Hamanari, Hinokuma Takenari, and Hajino Nakatomo, the three men who established and founded the [[Sensō-ji]] Buddhist temple. Sanja Matsuri is held on the third weekend of every May at [[Asakusa Shrine]]. Its prominent parades revolve around three ''[[mikoshi]]'' (portable shrines referenced in the festival's name), as well as traditional music and dancing. Over the course of three days, the festival attracts 1.5 to 2 million locals and tourists every year.<ref name="metro">{{cite web |url=http://metropolis.co.jp/tokyo/685/feature.asp |title=Festival Frenzy |accessdate=2008-03-05 |work=[[Metropolis (free magazine)|Metropolis]] |author=Graham, Fiona |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080221001537/http://www.metropolis.co.jp/tokyo/685/feature.asp <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-02-21}}</ref>
==History== Like many [[japanese festival|Japanese festivals]], Sanja Matsuri is a religious celebration. It is a weekend-long Shinto festival that is dedicated to the ''[[kami]]'' (spirits) of three men. It is believed that two fishermen—brothers named Hinokuma Hamanari and Hinokuma Takenari—found a statuette of the [[Bodhisattva]] [[Kannon]] caught in a fishing net in the [[Sumida River]] on the early morning of March 18, 628.<ref name="wgs">{{cite web |url=http://www.senso-ji.jp/guide/komagata_e.html |title=Guide to Senso Ji's Halls – Komagatado Hall |accessdate=2014-05-08 |}}</ref> The third man, a wealthy landlord named Hajino Nakatomo, heard about the discovery, approached the brothers and converted them to [[Buddhism]]. The three men then devoted their lives to the Buddhist faith and consecrated the statue in a small temple.<ref name="asakusashrine">{{cite web |url=http://www.asakusajinja.jp/english/ |title=Asakusa Shrine |accessdate=2008-03-21}}</ref> This temple, now known as the [[Sensō-ji]], currently houses the Kannon statue and is the oldest temple in Tokyo.
The Sanja Matsuri appears to have many forms that date back as early as the 7th century, as well as several names such as "Kannon Matsuri" and "Asakusa Matsuri".<ref name="history">{{cite web |url=http://www.asakusajinja.jp/sanjamatsuri/yurai.html |script-title=ja:三社祭とは? |accessdate=2008-03-21 |language=Japanese}}</ref> Sanja Matsuri's present day form was established during the [[Edo period]]. In 1649, ''[[shōgun]]'' [[Tokugawa Iemitsu]] commissioned the construction of [[Asakusa Shrine]], a [[Shinto shrine]] dedicated to the three ''kami''. The existence of this shrine helped to solidify the festival's importance as well as its current structure and organization.<ref name="bella">{{cite web |url=http://www.bellaonline.com/articles/art29889.asp |title=Japanese Festivals — Sanja Matsuri (Day 2) |accessdate=2008-03-05 |author=Turner, Taisha |work=BellaOnline}}</ref>
==Description of events==
[[File:Asakusa Matsuri Senso-ji May06.JPG|right|thumb|Asakusa Sanja Festival – a portable Shrine lifted in front of Sensō-ji temple.]]
Religious in origin, Sanja Matsuri is primarily a festival of celebration. The atmosphere around [[Asakusa]] during the weekend of the festival is charged and energetic. People continuously flood the streets surrounding the Sensō-ji and flutes, whistles, chanting and ''[[taiko]]'' (traditional Japanese drums) can be heard throughout the district.
The festival's main attractions are three Asakusa Shrine-owned ''[[mikoshi]]'' that appear on the third and final day of the festival. These three elaborate, black [[lacquer]]ed-wood shrines are built to act as miniature, portable versions of Asakusa Shrine. Decorated with gold sculptures and painted with [[gold leaf]], each ''mikoshi'' weighs approximately one ton and cost [[Japanese Yen|¥]]40 million ($390,760 in 2008) to construct.<ref name="metro"/> They are carried on four long poles lashed together with ropes, and each needs approximately 40 people dispersed evenly to safely carry them. Throughout the day, a total of about 500 people participate in carrying each shrine.<ref name="metro"/>
Because of the importance of these three ''mikoshi'', they are spectacles as they are carried through the streets. The areas immediately surrounding each shrine are busy with people, and as they are carried, they are shaken and bounced vehemently. This action is believed to intensify the power of the ''[[kami]]'' that are seated in the shrines and helps to bestow good luck upon their respective neighborhoods.<ref name="excelloz">{{cite web |url=http://www.excelloz.com/Travel_guide/Tokyo/Sanja_Matsuri_Festival_of_Asakusa_Shrine_Tokyo.html |title=Sanja Matsuri: Unique traditional Festival of Japan in Asakusa, Tokyo |accessdate=2008-03-05 |author=Miller, David |work=Excelloz Travel}}</ref> It is not unusual for there to be someone standing on the poles supporting the ''mikoshi'' shouting and waving in order to help direct the people carrying the shrine. This sense of direction can be essential when trying to keep the one ton ''mikoshi'' from accidentally colliding with street-side shops and causing considerable damage.<ref name="metro"/>
While the three primary ''mikoshi'' are the most important objects roaming the streets during the Sanja Matsuri, approximately 100 other smaller ''mikoshi'' are paraded through the neighborhood on Saturday. Of these shrines, several are solely carried by women or small children.<ref name="metro"/>
===Day by day===
[[File:Sunday night parade Sanja Matsuri 2006.JPG|thumb|People paraded through the Nakamise during Sanja Matsuri.]] [[File:Float during Sanja Matsuri 2006.JPG|right|thumb|A music float is carried down [[Sensō-ji#Nakamise-dōri|Nakamise-dōri]] late Sunday night]]
Though not a part of the festivities, the official start of the Sanja Matsuri begins on Thursday with an important religious ceremony. This ceremony requires Asakusa Shrine's [[kannushi|head priest]] to perform a ritual that moves the enshrined ''kami'' of the three men at Asakusa Shrine to the three ''mikoshi'' that will be paraded around the Asakusa during the weekend.<ref name="schedule">{{cite web |url=http://www.asakusajinja.jp/sanjamatsuri/nittei.html |script-title=ja:日程 |accessdate=2008-03-21 |language=Japanese}}</ref> By opening the small doors located on each ''mikoshi'' (the interior is obscured to the public by a small cotton curtain), the three spirits are invited into the miniature shrines where they will reside for the duration of the festival.<ref name="metro"/>
The festival's more publicized beginning starts on Friday when the {{nihongo|''Daigyōretsu''|大行列||literally "large parade"}} is held.<ref name="excelloz"/> This famous 19-block grand procession down Yanagi Street and [[Sensō-ji#Nakamise-dōri|Nakamise-dōri]] to Asakusa Shrine is an event that is used to energize the community. It is most known for its participants' lavish costumes, such as [[heron]]-hooded dancers, [[geisha]] and city officials wearing ''[[hakama]]'' (traditional Japanese clothing).<ref name="metro"/> Musicians, performers and dancers also parade down the streets of Asakusa in traditional Japanese attire during the procession. In the evening, six ''mikoshi'' from the most central neighborhoods are sent parading through the streets on the shoulders of several dozen people.<ref name="metro"/>
On the following day, Saturday, approximately 100 ''mikoshi'' from the 44 Asakusa districts gather at the [[Kaminarimon]].<ref name="bella"/> They are then paraded through Nakamise-dōri and stop at the [[Hōzōmon]] where they pay their respects to [[Kannon]], the Goddess of Mercy. Afterwards, the ''mikoshi'' are carried to [[Asakusa Shrine]] where [[Shinto]] priests bless and purify them for the coming year.<ref name="bella"/> When the ceremony is completed, they are then carried back and paraded through their respective neighborhoods.
Sanja Matsuri's most important events occurs on the following Sunday. The procession of the three Asakusa Shrine-owned ''mikoshi'' begin their march down Nakamise-dōri toward the Kaminarimon early Sunday morning. These three elaborate shrines honor and represent the three men responsible for founding the [[Sensō-ji]]. During this final day of the festival, these important ''mikoshi'' are split up in order to visit and bestow blessing to all 44 districts of downtown and residential Asakusa. When evening falls, the three shrines find their way back to Asakusa Shrine in another grand procession that lasts late into the night.<ref name="digital">{{cite web |url=http://www.digitalmatsuri.com/?p=3 |title=The Asakusa Sanja Matsuri |accessdate=2008-04-08 |date=2006-05-21 |work=The Digital Matsuri Project}}</ref>
==Other attractions==
In addition to the traditional events, Sanja Matsuri has several other popular draws. For example, festival goers can visit hundreds of shops found in the Nakamise, a street connecting the Kaminarimon and the Hōzōmon. Many small food stands are also erected in the surrounding areas for the entire weekend. [[Yakuza]] members also proudly show off their tattoos.<ref name="asiarooms">{{cite web |url=http://www.asiarooms.com/travel-guide/japan/japan-festivals-&-events/sanja-matsuri-festival.html |title=Sanja Matsuri Festival |accessdate=2008-06-30 |work=AsiaRooms.com}}</ref>
Other spectacles that draw crowds are the [[Geisha]] and ''[[taiko]]'' performances that take place at specific times throughout the weekend. On Saturday and Sunday, Geisha that don their traditional attire put on performances from 1–3 p.m. on the second floor of the Asakusa Kenban. These performances, which require visitors to purchase tickets, have been ranked as one of the 10 best Geisha shows in all of Japan.<ref name="about">{{cite web |url=http://gojapan.about.com/od/geisha/tp/bestgeishashow.htm |title=Top 10 Geisha Shows |accessdate=2008-04-08 |work=[[About.com]] |author=Mishima, Shizuko}}</ref> On Sunday afternoon, members of the Nihon Taiko Dojo, a prominent Tokyo ''taiko'' academy, perform a free half-hour traditional music show at Asakusa Shrine.<ref name="metro"/>
==Festival schedule== Though there are many activities during Sanja Matsuri that are not time dependent, there are a few events that start and stop at specific times throughout the weekend.

{{manual|article|date=March 2018}} [[File:Falls are the fifth most common event leading to an occupational fatality for oil and gas extraction workers.jpg|thumb|Worker hanging strapped into a safety harness during a fall rescue drill]] '''Suspension trauma''' ''(Syn. "orthostatic shock while suspended")'', also known as '''harness hang syndrome (HHS)''', '''suspension syndrome''', or '''[[orthostatic intolerance]]''', is an effect which occurs when the human body is held upright without any movement for a period of time. If the person is strapped into a harness or tied to an upright object they will eventually suffer the [[central ischaemic response]] (commonly known as [[fainting]]). Fainting while remaining vertical increases the risk of death from [[cerebral hypoxia]].<ref>Seddon P.: ''Harness suspension: review and evaluation of existing information''. In: Health and Safety Executive - CONTRACT RESEARCH REPORT 451/2002, page 3, [http://www.hse.gov.uk/research/crr_pdf/2002/crr02451.pdf hier online]</ref> Since there is no evidence that these effects are specifically due to trauma, or caused by the harness itself, climbing medicine authorities have argued against the terminology of suspension trauma or harness hang syndrome and instead termed this simply "suspension syndrome". <ref>Hawkins SC, Simon RB, Beissinger JP, Simon D. Vertical Aid: Essential Wilderness Medicine for Climbers, Trekkers, and Mountaineers. New York: The Countryman Press, 2017.</ref>
People at risk of suspension trauma include people using industrial harnesses ([[fall arrest]] systems, [[abseiling]] systems, [[confined space]] systems), people using harnesses for sporting purposes ([[caving]], [[climbing]], [[parachuting]], etc.), [[stunt]] performers, circus performers, and occupations that require the use of harnesses and suspension systems in general. Suspension shock can also occur in medical environments, for similar reasons.{{citation needed|date=July 2012}}
==Cause== The most common cause is accidents in which the person remains motionless suspended in a harness for longer periods of time. Motionlessness may have several causes including fatigue, hypoglycemia, hypothermia or traumatic brain injury.
==Symptoms== Onset of symptoms may be after just a few minutes, but usually occurs after at least 20 minutes of free hanging. Typical symptoms are pallor, sweating, shortness of breath, blurred vision, dizziness, nausea, hypotension and numbness of the legs. Eventually it leads to [[fainting]], which may result in death due to oxygen deprivation of the brain.
==Treatment== If someone is stranded in a harness, but is not unconscious or injured, and has something to kick against or stand on (such as a rock ledge or caving leg-loops) it is helpful for them to use their leg muscles by pushing against it every so often, to keep the blood pumping back to the torso. If the person is stranded in mid-air or is exhausted, then keeping the legs moving can be both beneficial and rather dangerous. On the one hand, exercising the leg muscles will keep the blood returning to the torso, but on the other hand, as the movements become weaker the leg muscles will continue to demand blood yet they will become much less effective at returning it to the body, and the moment the victim ceases moving their legs, the blood will immediately start to pool. "Pedaling an imaginary bicycle" should only be used as a last-ditch effort to prolong consciousness, because as soon as the "pedaling" stops, fainting will shortly follow. If it is impossible to rescue someone immediately, then it is necessary to raise their legs to a sitting position, which can be done with a loop of rigging tape behind the knees or specialized equipment from a rescue kit.
When workers are suspended in their safety harnesses for long periods, they may suffer from blood pooling in the lower body. This can lead to suspension trauma. Once a worker is back on the ground after a fall has been arrested on a fall protection system, a worker should be placed in the “W” position. The “W” position is where a worker sits upright on the ground with their back/chest straight and their legs bent so that their knees are in line with the bottom of their chin. For added stability, make sure that the worker’s feet stay flat on the ground. In this position, a KED board can still be used if there are any potential spinal injuries and a worker needs stabilization before transport.
Once the worker is in this position, they will need to stay in that position for at least 30 minutes. Try to leave the worker in this position until their symptoms begin to subside. The time in the “W” position will allow the pooled blood from the legs to be slowly re-introduced back into the body. By slowing the rate at which the pooled blood reaches different organs, you are giving the body more of an opportunity to filter the pooled blood and maintain internal homeostasis. http://www.rigidlifelines.com/blog/entry/suspension-traumasymptoms-and-treatment
==Prevention== Prevention of suspension trauma is preferable to dealing with its consequences. Specific recommendations for individuals doing technical ropework are to avoid exhausting themselves so much that they end up without the energy to keep moving, and making sure everyone in a group is trained in single rope rescue techniques, especially the [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O-ht7HgQZkQ "single rope pickoff"], a rather difficult technical maneuver that must be practiced frequently for smooth performance.
==See also== *[[Reflow syndrome]], which occurs when toxins that accumulated in pooled blood suddenly return to the body when the person lies down following suspension trauma *[[Compartment syndrome]], a dangerous condition that sometimes occurs with suspension trauma

'''''The Astronaut Wives Club''''' is an [[United States|American]] period drama television series developed by [[Stephanie Savage]] for [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]. It is based on [[Lily Koppel]]'s [[The Astronaut Wives Club (book)|book of the same name]].<ref name=ord/> The series tells the story of the wives of the [[Mercury Seven]]—America's first group of [[astronauts]]. Actresses [[Dominique McElligott]], [[Yvonne Strahovski]], [[JoAnna Garcia|Joanna García Swisher]], [[Erin Cummings]], [[Azure Parsons]], [[Zoe Boyle]], and [[Odette Annable]] play the roles of the astronauts' wives.
''The Astronaut Wives Club'' premiered on June 18, 2015.<ref name="Deadline Hollywood">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/04/astronaut-wives-club-premiere-date-summer-abc-1201412805/|title=ABC’s ‘Astronaut Wives Club’ Gets Summer Premiere Date|date=April 20, 2015|website=Deadline Hollywood|accessdate=May 24, 2015}}</ref> Following the completion of its run, the series' developer noted the series had been planned as a miniseries, telling a complete story.<ref name="Astronaut Canceled">{{cite web|url=http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/the-astronaut-wives-club-cancelled-by-abc-no-season-two-37828/|title='The Astronaut Wives Club' Cancelled by ABC; No Season Two|work=TV Series Finale|date=August 23, 2015|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}</ref> However, co-creator Stephanie Savage revealed in an interview with Variety that the producers were interested in making the series an anthology in case it gained a renewal for a second season. Possible seasons would have featured wives of men in the 1920s, wives of World War II soldiers, wives of men who work on Wall Street, and wives of men in the 1980s, among other possible scenarios.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://variety.com/2015/tv/news/astronaut-wives-club-finale-stephanie-savage-1201572669/|title=‘Astronaut Wives Club’ Finale: Stephanie Savage Prepares for ABC Drama’s Final Descent|last=Friedlander|first=Whitney|date=2015-08-20|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-27}}</ref>
[[Mill Creek Entertainment]] announced The Astronaut Wives Club on DVD.

==Reception== ''The Astronaut Wives Club'' has received mixed reviews. Review aggregator site, [[Metacritic]], has given the series a "mixed or average" score of 60 out of 100, based on 23 critics.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/the-astronaut-wives-club |title=The Astronaut Wives Club: Season 1 |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=June 18, 2015}}</ref> On another review aggregator site, [[Rotten Tomatoes]], it holds a 50% rating, based on 28 reviews. The critical consensus there reads: "''The Astronaut Wives'' relies on poorly paced storylines and clichéd characters, both used in service of a fact-based narrative that would have been better served in a more serious context."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/the-astronaut-wives-club/s01/ |title=The Astronaut Wives Club: Season 1 |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes |accessdate=June 18, 2015}}</ref>

page.title: The Mrs. Carter Show World Tour

revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Infobox concert tour | image = Mrs. Carter.jpg | image_caption = Promotional poster for the tour | image_size = 220px | border = yes | artist = [[Beyoncé]] | albums = | start_date = {{Start date|2013|04|15}} | end_date = {{End date|2014|03|27}} | number_of_legs = 9 | number_of_shows = {{ubl|60 in Europe|44 in North America|18 in Oceania|10 in Latin America|132 total}} | gross = $229.7 million (132 shows) | last_tour = [[Revel Presents: Beyoncé Live]]
(2012) | this_tour = '''The Mrs. Carter Show World Tour'''
(2013–14) | next_tour = [[On the Run Tour (Beyoncé and Jay Z)|On the Run Tour]]
(2014) }} '''The Mrs. Carter Show World Tour''' was the fifth [[concert tour]] by American singer [[Beyoncé]]. Announced in February 2013 with initial dates in Europe and North America, the tour contained seven legs and 132 shows. It began in [[Belgrade]], [[Serbia]] on April 15, 2013 and concluded in [[Lisbon]], [[Portugal]] on March 27, 2014. Its title is a reference to her marriage with American rapper [[Jay-Z|Shawn "Jay-Z" Carter]], who made multiple guest appearances throughout the tour. The tour featured royal themes with the singer emulating different queens through her fashion for which she collaborated with numerous designers and fashion houses. The [[set list]] of the shows in 2013 included songs from all four [[studio albums]] of Beyoncé's solo career. After the release of her [[Beyoncé (album)|eponymous fifth studio album]], the 2014 shows were changed to incorporate tracks from the album. The tour was lauded by [[music journalism|music critics]] who praised Beyoncé for her energetic performances, dancing and vocal abilities. Following the announcement of the tour, all the tickets made available for the shows sold out, which prompted more dates to be added to the itinerary. The tour grossed $188.6 million in 2013 and the 2014 shows grossed $41.1 million, bringing the tour's total gross revenue to $229.7 million. This made The Mrs. Carter Show World Tour the highest-grossing female and solo tour of 2013. Performances of numerous songs from the tour were broadcast and behind-the-scenes footage was released. == Background == [[File:Jay-Z Beyonce.jpg|thumbnail|left|180px|Beyoncé's husband [[Jay-Z]] (real name, Shawn Carter), served as an inspiration for the title of the tour.]] During a press conference for [[Super Bowl XLVII]] on January 31, 2013, Beyoncé revealed that she would make an announcement after her performance at the [[Super Bowl XLVII halftime show|halftime show]] and added that "fans should just stay tuned to see".{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a455638/beyonce-to-make-tour-announcement-after-super-bowl.html|title=Beyoncé to make tour announcement after Super Bowl|work=[[Digital Spy]]|first=Sam|last=Rigby|date=February 1, 2013|accessdate=February 18, 2013}} Beyoncé announced the tour and its name after her performance the Super Bowl XLVII halftime show on February 3. The tour's title refers to her marriage with [[Jay-Z|Shawn 'Jay-Z' Carter]]. However, the official poster of the tour with the name written on it was leaked on the ticket's website [[Live Nation (events promoter)|Live Nation]] prior to the official announcement.{{cite web|last=Greenwald|first=David|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1537597/beyonces-world-tour-the-mrs-carter-show |title=Beyoncé's World Tour: The Mrs. Carter Show?|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=February 1, 2013|accessdate=February 5, 2013}} It shows Beyoncé wearing a Victorian golden royal top and a crown, referencing [[Elizabeth I of England|Queen Elizabeth I]].{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/shortcuts/2013/feb/04/beyonce-mrs-carter-show|title=Beyoncé and the Mrs Carter Show|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=February 4, 2013|accessdate=April 2, 2013}} Rosie Swash of ''[[The Guardian]]'' described it as a "visual stamp of authority".{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/the-womens-blog-with-jane-martinson/2013/feb/05/beyonce-calling-herself-mrs-carter|title=Why is Beyoncé calling herself Mrs Carter?|newspaper=The Guardian|first=Rosie|last=Swash|date=February 5, 2013|accessdate=April 2, 2013}} Along with the tour's name, initial dates in Europe and North America were announced, and later more were added in Latin America, Australia, and New Zealand.{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2013/02/03/beyonce-announces-the-mrs-carter-show-world-tour-dates|title=Beyoncé Announces 'The Mrs. Carter Show World Tour' Dates and promotes her fifth album yet to be released|work=[[Rap-Up]]|date=February 3, 2013|accessdate=February 4, 2013}} Following the announcement of the tour's title, Beyoncé was criticized by several critics and [[feminist]]s alike for entitling it after her husband's name as she has been regarded as a feminist. Questions were raised about how Beyoncé agreed to be known as a bride of another celebrity person.{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2013/02/04/beyonc_s_mrs_carter_show_world_tour_why_use_her_married_name.html|title=Who Run the World? Husbands?|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|first=Aisha|last=Harris|date=February 4, 2013|accessdate=July 10, 2014}} During an interview with ''[[Vogue (British magazine)|Vogue]]'', Beyoncé described herself as a "modern-day feminist" and further spoke about her decision to reference her husband's name: "I feel like Mrs. Carter is who I am, but more bold and more fearless than I've ever been..... It comes from knowing my purpose and really meeting myself once I saw my child. I was like, 'OK, this is what you were born to do'. The purpose of my body became completely different."{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1704878/beyonce-feminist-vogue-uk.jhtml|title=Beyonce Considers Herself A 'Modern-Day Feminist'|publisher=[[MTV News]]|first=Jocelyn|last=Vena|date=April 3, 2013|accessdate=April 3, 2013}} After the second European leg was announced on December 11, 2013, a new poster was revealed and used for the promotion of all the newly added shows.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a537382/beyonce-announces-uk-ireland-tour-dates-for-2014.html#~oGXxO8rwWdv2ky|title=Beyoncé announces UK, Ireland tour dates for 2014|work=Digital Spy|first=Greg|last=Laing|date=December 11, 2013|accessdate=June 30, 2014}} == Development == [[File:End of Time Montreal 2013.jpg|thumbnail|upright|215px|Beyoncé performing "End of Time" with the French dancing duo Les Twins and her female background dancers as pyrotechnics fell on stage.]] The concert at [[The O2 Arena|The O2 Arena]] in London was announced on February 3, along with a short advertisement for the tour; an extended version of the clip appeared in late February. It shows Beyoncé dressed with a golden corset and a royal gown with jewels. She is seen walking into a dance hall in [[slow-motion]] with several servants and a DJ, dressed as a [[jester]] tries to distract her. The end of the advertisement shows [[black-and-white]] snippets of behind-the-scenes footage of the video.{{cite web|url=http://www.capitalfm.com/artists/beyonce-knowles/news/the-mrs-carter-show-world-tour-extended-trailer/|title=Beyonce Stars In New Extended Trailer For 'The Mrs Carter Show' World Tour – Video|publisher=Capital FM|date=February 25, 2013|accessdate=July 10, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://uk.eonline.com/news/390755/beyonc-s-mrs-carter-show-tour-extended-teaser-queen-bey-is-royally-fierce-in-majestic-getup-watch-now|title=Beyoncé's "Mrs. Carter Show Tour" Extended Teaser: Queen Bey Is Royally Fierce in Majestic Getup—Watch Now!|publisher=[[E!]]|first=Alexis|last=L. Loinaz|date=February 22, 2013|accessdate=February 26, 2013}} Alexis L. Loinaz of [[E!]] compared her aristocratic look in the video to [[Marie Antoinette]], Queen Elizabeth I, and [[Lady Gaga]]. In March 2013, Beyoncé posted a new poster for the tour on her official [[Facebook]] page showing her striking four different poses, wearing a blond wig, a white top and blue shorts.{{cite web|url=http://uk.eonline.com/news/394534/beyonc-goes-blond-in-new-mrs-carter-show-world-tour-promo-pic|title=Beyoncé Goes Blond in New Mrs. Carter Show World Tour Promo Pic|publisher= E!|first=Peter|last=Gicas|date=March 5, 2013|accessdate=March 17, 2013}} In May 2013, Beyoncé launched an online store for the tour in which different clothes were available for purchase.{{cite web|url=http://style.mtv.com/2013/05/03/beyonce-mrs-carter-show-store/|title=Beyonce Opens The Mrs. Carter Show Online Store|publisher=MTV|first=Gaby|last=Wilson|date=May 3, 2013|accessdate=July 7, 2014}} The following month, she added a limited edition to her [[Heat (perfume)|Heat]] line of perfumes, titled Heat: The Mrs. Carter Show World Tour. Inspired by the tour, Beyoncé stated that the fragrance was meant to "give them [fans] a special remembrance of this tour and... reflect the power, passion and playfulness I put into my performances".{{cite web|url=http://www.beyonceparfums.com/heat-the-mrs-carter-show-world-tour|title=Heat The Mrs. Carter Show World Tour|publisher=Beyonceparfums.com|accessdate=June 13, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130616054435/http://www.beyonceparfums.com/heat-the-mrs-carter-show-world-tour|archivedate=June 16, 2013|df=}} On April 24, 2013, it was announced by Beyoncé's publicist that all photographers except Beyoncé's personal photographer Frank Micelotta, were banned from the tour stating that "no photo credentials" will be present. The ban was interpreted as a reaction to the "unflattering" pictures from Beyoncé's Super Bowl XLVII halftime performance showing her "jubilant exertions", that appeared on websites such as [[Gawker]] and [[BuzzFeed]]. The pictures were not removed even after her publicist Yvette Noel-Schure asked the websites through an e-mail to change their articles, using "some better photos".{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/apr/24/beyonce-bans-photographers-mrs-carter|title=Beyoncé bans press photographers from Mrs Carter world tour|work=The Guardian|date=April 24, 2013|first=Sean|last=Michaels|accessdate=April 24, 2013}} On May 13, 2013, the general counsel of the [[National Press Photographers Association]] (NPPA) Mickey H. Osterreicher, wrote a letter to Noel-Schure on behalf of 19 other organizations requesting from him to "immediately revise your guidelines to restore photo credentialing" for the rest of the tour in Europe and the US.{{cite web|url=http://www.fuse.tv/2013/05/beyonce-mrs-carter-show-world-tour-photo-ban|title=Press Photographers to Beyonce: You Don't Run the World|publisher=[[Fuse (TV channel)|Fuse]]|first=Nicole|last=James|date=May 16, 2013|accessdate=July 9, 2014}} For the tour, the singer took part in "Miss A Meal", a food-donation campaign and supported the charity [[Goodwill Industries|Goodwill]] during her tour, where fans were asked to bring food, clothes and household goods at the stops.{{cite web|url=http://www.essence.com/2013/04/15/beyonc%C3%A9-teams-goodwill-new-tour/|title=Beyoncé Teams Up with Goodwill on New Tour|work=[[Essence (magazine)|Essence]]|first=Derrick|last=Bryson Taylor|date=April 15, 2013|accessdate=April 24, 2013}} Throughout the tour, an auction for the campaign was held by Beyoncé and her mother, [[Tina Knowles]] on the website [[Charitybuzz]] in which the auction value was $25,000. The winner got a chance to work behind the scenes of Beyoncé's concert in Los Angeles and assist Knowles in the wardrobe department, got a VIP ticket for the concert and had a personal meeting with the singer.{{cite web|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/entertainment/music/Beyonce-auctions-tour-experience-for-25000.html|title=Beyoncé auctions tour experience for $25,000|publisher=[[Philadelphia Media Network]]|first=Jennifer|last=Nguyen|date=June 5, 2013|accessdate=June 7, 2013}} Eight hundred dancers auditioned to be included in Beyoncé's performance at the Super Bowl XLVII halftime show and a selected group of them, consisting only of females, were chosen for the performance as well as for the tour.{{cite web|url=http://www.vibe.com/photo-gallery/10-things-you-need-know-about-beyonce-mrs-carter-show-tour/?page=5|title=10 Things You Need To Know About Beyoncé's 'The Mrs. Carter Show' Tour|work=[[Vibe (magazine)|Vibe]]|first=Chris|last=Yuscavage|date=April 17, 2013|page=5 and 6|accessdate=April 22, 2013}} French dancing duo [[Les Twins]] also accompanied Beyoncé on stage performing [[street dance]]s. Three backing singers The Mamas, and an eleven-piece female band who had also supported the singer during her previous tours performed during the concerts.{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/beyonce-wraps-mrs-carter-tour-with-high-flying-decadence-20131223|title=Beyonce Wraps 'Mrs. Carter' Tour With High-Flying Decadence|work=Rolling Stone|first=Stacey|last=Anderson|date=December 23, 2013|accessdate=July 9, 2014}} Two stages were used during the performances: a main stage where the singer performed throughout most of the concert and a [[B-stage]] closer to the audience where she was transferred with a rope, flying over the crowd midway through the set, performing three songs there. The [[set list]] of the 2013 portion of the tour included approximately twenty five songs from Beyoncé's four solo studio albums: ''[[Dangerously in Love]]'' (2003), ''[[B'Day (Beyoncé album)|B'Day]]'' (2006), ''[[I Am... Sasha Fierce]]'' (2008), and ''[[4 (Beyoncé album)|4]]'' (2011). The majority of the songs originated from ''4'' – seven songs were performed from that album.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/concert-review-beyonce-at-staples-578562|title=Beyonce Slays at Staples Center: Concert Review|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|first=Shirley|last=Halperin|date=July 2, 2013|accessdate=June 30, 2014}} Many of the tracks performed contained different choreographies and arrangements compared to the previous performances by the singer; several of them were intertwined with other artists' material.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/live-music-reviews/10021121/Beyonce-Mrs-Carter-Show-LG-Arena-Birmingham-review.html|title=Beyoncé, Mrs Carter Show, LG Arena Birmingham, review|work=The Daily Telegraph|first=Bernadette|last=McNulty|date=April 27, 2013|accessdate=June 30, 2014}} For the 2014 shows many of the previously performed songs were removed and eight new songs from Beyoncé's fifth [[Beyoncé (album)|self-titled studio album]] were added to the concert's set list.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/thesound/a552995/6-reasons-why-beyonces-mrs-carter-show-tour-is-better-than-ever.html|title=6 reasons why Beyoncé's 'Mrs Carter Show' tour is better than ever|work=Digital Spy|first=Robert|last=Copsey|date=February 21, 2014|accessdate=June 30, 2014}} == Fashion == [[File:Beyonce Freakum Dress Live.jpg|thumbnail|Beyoncé and her female dancers performing "Freakum Dress" during a concert. Daily Telegraph]]|first=Olivia|last=Bergin|date=April 12, 2013|accessdate=April 13, 2013}} Several costumes were also designed by Emilio Pucci's Peter Dundas who described them as a "modern take on glamour", taking them from his fall/winter 2013 collection. He focused on the singer being able to perform the choreography during her performances.{{cite web|url=http://blog.chron.com/shopgirl/2013/04/take-a-look-at-puccis-costumes-for-beyonce-world-tour/#11355-1|title=Take a look at Pucci's costumes for Beyoncé world tour|work=[[Houston Chronicle]]|first=Joy|last=Sewing|date=April 15, 2013|accessdate=April 16, 2013}} [[Stuart Weitzman]] designed the shoes for Beyoncé, her back-up dancers and band collaborating with stylists Ty Hunter, Raquel Smith, and Beyoncé's mother [[Tina Knowles]].{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/style/2013/04/15/beyonce-shoes-designer-stuart-weitzman/2084263/|title=Beyonce's pumped-up kicks for Mrs. Carter tour revealed|work=[[USA Today]]|first=Lorena|last=Blas|date=April 15, 2013|accessdate=April 15, 2013}} Weitzman created them in different colors with military elements. Beyoncé wanted Weitzman to focus on her being able to dance wearing the shoes without noticing they were on her feet.{{cite web|url=http://stylenews.peoplestylewatch.com/2013/04/15/beyonce-mrs-carter-show-tour-stuart-weitzman/|title=Exclusive First Look: Beyonce's Sexy 'Mrs. Carter' Shoes|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=April 15, 2013|first=Alex|last=Apatoff|accessdate=July 10, 2013}} One of Beyoncé's costumes which was worn during the first concerts was a gold bodysuit designed by The Blonds embellished with golden breasts complete with a nipple detail. The costume was a collaboration between the group, Beyoncé, Knowles, and Hunter. It was hand embroidered in 600 hours with approximately 30,000 Swarovski crystals.{{cite web|url=http://fashionista.com/2013/04/the-blonds-on-creating-beyonces-blinged-out-boob-bustier/|title=The Blonds on Creating Beyoncé's Blinged Out Boob Bustier|publisher=Fashionista|first=Marcus|last=Holmund|date=April 17, 2013|accessdate=April 18, 2013}} According to The Blonds, it was meant to give the illusion of being covered in crystallized honey and reflect Beyoncé's personality for the tour. They were inspired by Beyoncé's songs of female empowerment{{cite web|last=DelliCarpini|first=Gregory|title=Beyonce's Mrs. Carter Show Tour Opener: The 5 Best Looks and Designer Commentary|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/list/1558315/beyonces-mrs-carter-show-tour-opener-the-5-best-looks-and-designer-commentary|work=Billboard|date=April 16, 2013|accessdate=April 17, 2013}} and female nudes painted by [[Tamara de Lempicka]].{{cite web|last=Blalock|first=Meghan|title=Beyonce's Most Scandalous Tour Costume Ever: Exclusive Details from Designers, The Blonds|url=http://news.instyle.com/2013/04/16/beyonce-nipple-costume-mrs-carter-show-world-tour/|work=[[InStyle]]|date=April 16, 2013|accessdate=April 18, 2013}} The costume received wide media and fan attention and divided critics' opinions.{{cite web|url=http://uk.eonline.com/news/408425/beyonc-flashes-faux-nipples-in-raunchy-gold-outfit-for-mrs-carter-show-world-tour|title=Beyoncé Flashes Faux Nipples in Raunchy Gold Outfit for Mrs. Carter Show World Tour|publisher=E! News|first=Alexis|last=L. Loinaz|date=April 16, 2013|accessdate=April 16, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://style.time.com/2013/04/17/beyonce-kicks-off-mrs-carter-tour-with-faux-nipples/|title=Beyoncé Kicks Off Mrs. Carter Tour With Faux Nipples|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|first=Kristene|last=Quan|date=April 17, 2013|accessdate=April 22, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2013/04/17/beyonce-slammed-for-golden-breast-costume/|title=Beyonce slammed for golden breast costume|publisher=Fox News Channel|date=April 17, 2013|accessdate=June 30, 2014}} ''[[InStyle]]''{{'}}s Meghan Blalock described the costume as the "most scandalous" that the singer has worn in her career. For the 2014 shows, the singer wore numerous new designs collaborating again with DSQUARED2, Givenchy, Pucci and Weitzman as well as with new designers such as [[Tom Ford]], [[Versace]] and Karen Langley.{{cite web|url=http://www.out.com/fashion/2014/04/08/mrs-carters-fashion-tour-beyonc%C3%A9s-stylist-ty-hunter#slide-1|title=Mrs. Carter's Fashion: Tour With Beyoncé's Stylist Ty Hunter|work=Out|date=April 8, 2014|pages=1–14|accessdate=June 30, 2014}} [[File:Grown Woman 2013 Montreal.jpg|thumbnail|left|Beyoncé performing "Grown Woman" with her female background dancers, wearing animal printed dresses. The projection behind them showed African-inspired video projection.]] Beyoncé's makeup for the tour focused on trying to emulate cosmic stars with the underlying themes based on the [[stratosphere]]. Other references used as inspiration for the makeup included: [[film noir]], [[London in the 1960s|60's London]], cyber beauty, cosmic constellations, and [[Cat|felines]].{{cite web|url=http://www.beyonce.com/news/the-mrs-carter-show-beauty-edition|title=The Mrs. Carter Show: Beauty Edition|publisher=Beyonce.com|date=July 29, 2013|accessdate=July 29, 2013}} The tourbook for The Mrs. Carter Show was meant to artistically illustrate all the different visual aspects of the tour through multi-media collage and [[Photo manipulation|image manipulation]]. By using collage, Beyoncé's team created images inspired by the singer and her songs and image manipulation was explored, with photos being [[solarisation|solarized]], [[layers (digital image editing)|layered]] and stacked. With the tourbook, fans had an opportunity to "bring a part of the tour home with them", as Beyoncé's team stated.{{cite web|url=http://www.beyonce.com/news/undressing-the-tourbook|title=Undressing the tourbook|publisher=Beyonce.com|date=August 6, 2013|accessdate=August 7, 2013}} A dress created by Amato Haute Couture's Furne One which was worn by Beyoncé for the tour book was originally designed and worn by Estonian singer-songwriter [[Kerli]] during her ''[[Utopia (EP)|Utopia]]'' [[Extended play|EP]] photoshoot who praised the look after seeing it.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1560054/beyonces-mrs-carter-show-look-borrows-from-kerli-nicki-minaj|title=Beyonce's 'Mrs. Carter Show' Look Borrows from Kerli, Nicki Minaj|first=David|last=Greenwald|work=Billboard|date=April 29, 2013|accessdate=April 30, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.vibe.com/article/kerli-takes-shot-beyonc%C3%A9-stealing-her-style|title=Kerli Takes A Shot At Beyoncé For Stealing Her Style|first=Evan|last=Schwartz|work=[[Vibe (magazine)|Vibe]]|date=April 29, 2013|accessdate=April 30, 2013}} The concert included several costume changes during which video interludes were projected on the screen during the singer's absence. An [[18th Century France]] influence was found in the white-powder makeup and the opening costume as well as a [[Louis XVI]] theme throughout the show with oversized wigs and bustiers. The dresses and looks were also noted to channel queens Marie Antionette, [[Cleopatra]], and Elizabeth I by several critics.{{cite web|url=http://www.instyle.co.uk/celebrity/news/beyonce-brings-the-mrs-carter-show-world-tour-to-london|title=Beyonce brings the Mrs Carter Show World Tour to London|work=InStyle|date=April 30, 2013|accessdate=May 13, 2013}} ''[[The Observer]]''{{'}}s [[Kitty Empire]] described the concert as a [[fashion]] show with a regal, ''[[Dangerous Liaisons]]'' theme.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/may/05/beyonce-mrs-carter-tour-o2-london-review|title=Beyoncé – review|work=[[The Observer]]|first=Kitty|last=Empire|date=May 5, 2013|accessdate=June 30, 2014}} Jocelyn Vena of MTV News described the costumes as "Eye-catching... dazzling... [and] provocative".{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1705767/beyonce-serbia-mrs-carter-tour-costume.jhtml|title=Beyonce Rocks 'Nipple' Bodysuit For 'Mrs. Carter' Tour Kickoff|publisher=MTV News|first=Jocelyn|last=Vena|date=April 16, 2013|accessdate=April 16, 2013}} Rosa Silverman of ''The Daily Telegraph'' commented that Beyoncé was "mesmerizing the crowds with her showstopping outfits... she took to the stage in a series of racy costumes that made no attempt to hide her famous curves."{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandpopmusic/10026829/Beyonce-dazzles-at-Londons-O2.html|title=Beyonce dazzles at London's O2|work=The Daily Telegraph|first=Rosa|last=Silverman|date=April 30, 2013|accessdate=May 6, 2013}} Erika Ramirez of ''Billboard'' commented that most of Beyoncé's "stunning" costumes were dazzled with sequins.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-juice/1558302/beyonce-kicks-off-mrs-carter-show-world-tour|title=Beyonce Kicks Off Mrs. Carter Show World Tour|work=Billboard|first=Erika|last=Ramirez|date=April 16, 2013|accessdate=April 16, 2013}} == Concert synopsis == === 2013 shows === {{double image|left|Get Me Bodied Beyonce 2013.jpg|180|Beyonce at Montreal 2013.jpg|180|Immediately after Beyoncé finished with the performance of "Get Me Bodied" with her background dancers, (''left'') they went in front of a holographic background continuing with "Baby Boy" (''right'').}} The concert opened with a pre-recorded video montage showing black and white footage of [[gothic architecture]] as well as dancers dressed in white, marching across a stage length screen, preparing to crown Beyoncé who was dressed as a queen. The montage continued as female dancers wearing hoop-skirt cages and masks started appearing on stage. The video wall raised afterwards and a brief pyrotechnics display began as Beyoncé appeared onstage standing for several seconds prior to the performance of "[[Run the World (Girls)]]" preceded by an extended timpani interlude. She sang the song while performing a choreography which included a routine of faux kicking her male dancers. "[[End of Time (song)|End of Time]]" followed with Beyoncé dancing as fireworks were also displayed on stage. "[[Flaws and All]]" was performed as the third song on the set list with Beyoncé dedicating it to her fan group, the BeyHive. "[[If I Were a Boy]]" was [[Mashup (music)|mashed]] with [[The Verve]]'s song "[[Bitter Sweet Symphony]]" taking the latter's string motif and incorporating several lines.{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/posts/la-et-ms-bet-experience-2013-beyonce-blows-through-staples-center-20130629,0,3534527.story|title=BET Experience 2013: Beyonce blows out Staples Center|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|first=Mikael|last=Wood|date=June 29, 2013|accessdate=July 11, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/beyonce/70022|title=Beyoncé makes nod to The Verve at London's O2 Arena|work=[[NME]]|date=April 30, 2013|accessdate=June 4, 2013}} "[[Get Me Bodied]]" saw Beyoncé interacting with the audience through [[call and response]], asking them to repeat "Hey, Mrs. Carter". "[[Baby Boy (Beyoncé song)|Baby Boy]]" was performed against a [[Holography|holographic background]] as Beyoncé and several female dancers performed synchronised moves in front of the screen which flashed realistic images of more identical dancers. The singer concluded the song with a [[Dutty Wine]] dance at the end of the performance, before immediately continuing with "[[Diva (Beyoncé song)|Diva]]" which was set to the [[groove (music)|groove]] of "[[Clique (song)|Clique]]". "[[Naughty Girl (Beyoncé song)|Naughty Girl]]" was later performed into a neon strip-lit with a snippet of [[Donna Summer]]'s "[[Love to Love You Baby (song)|Love to Love You Baby]]" interpolated within it. Beyoncé also performed a seductive dance in front of an open fire display onstage. "[[Party (Beyoncé song)|Party]]" was performed after with a prominent [[Las Vegas showgirl]] theme. For "[[Freakum Dress]]" two ballerinas appeared on stage and performed a choreography along with a video projection on the screen. Beyoncé later appeared in a deep-plunging, thigh-high split long red dress performing the song along with her dancers. {{double image|right|Beyonce 1+1 live (2).jpg|180|Beyonce B-Stage Montreal 2013.jpg|180|Beyoncé performing "1+1" seated on a piano. After the performance of the song, she flew with a wire to a B-stage, closer to the people in the crowd (''right'').}} For "[[I Care (Beyoncé song)|I Care]]" the singer was dressed in a black leather fedora, seated on a bar stool. Beyoncé sang "[[I Miss You (Beyoncé song)|I Miss You]]" while shadow dancing was illustrated on the screen behind her. "[[Schoolin' Life]]" was performed with a [[Laser lighting display|light show]] complete with '80s [[Neon lighting|neon lights]] while she performed a dance routine with her dancers. An uptempo version of "[[Why Don't You Love Me (Beyoncé song)|Why Don't You Love Me]]" with a choreography by Beyoncé and [[Les Twins]] was preceded by a video projection showing a vintage montage of her. The singer performed the song with a call and response interaction between her and the audience dressed in a 1920s fringed dress. The performance of "1+1" saw Beyoncé in a blue cat-suit kneeling and laying atop a grand piano. During the end of "1+1", she was transformed from the main stage to the "Bey-stage", located closer to the crowd with a wire through a cloud of glitter. "Irreplaceable" was performed after that with an audience sing-along. "Love on Top" and an abbreviated version of [[Destiny's Child]]'s "Survivor" followed; Beyoncé dedicated the latter song to the members of the aforementioned girl group, [[Kelly Rowland]] and [[Michelle Williams (singer)|Michelle Williams]]. Beyoncé was taken back to the main stage being transferred with the same wire. "[[Crazy in Love (Beyoncé song)|Crazy in Love]]" was the first song performed on the main stage with a new brassy arrangement, different from Beyoncé's other live performances of the song. During "[[Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)]]", she integrated a snippet from the song "[[The Jeffersons#Theme song|Movin' on Up]]". Images of pyramids, animated lions and elephants and a portrait of the singer wearing a [[Nefertiti]]-style crown were displayed on the screen before the performance of "Grown Woman", keeping in line with the song's African influence. During the performance, the singer and her dancers wore African-inspired costumes. A montage was shown with the song "[[I Was Here (song)|I Was Here]]" being played in the background showing footage of the singer with [[Barack Obama]], taking part in charity work, during a vacation with Jay-Z and excerpts of her 2013 performance at the Super Bowl. An [[a cappella]] performance of the opening lines of "[[I Will Always Love You#Beyoncé Knowles version|I Will Always Love You]]" preceded "Halo" as the closing song of the concert. "[[Green Light (Beyoncé song)|Green Light]]" and "[[Suga Mama]]" were used for the [[encore (concert)|encore]] of the concert at numerous stops. === 2014 shows === {{double image|left||180||180|The 2014 European leg of the concert featured performances of songs from Beyoncé's fifth studio album; among them were "Drunk in Love" for which the singer appeared seated on a chair and surrounded by smoke (''left'') and "Blow" (''right'').}} The performances of the songs that had already been performed during the 2013 shows remained the same; however some of them were shortened and mixed together. Many new songs from the singer's fifth album were added to the set list with a specific staging and theme. The projections shown on the stage followed the concept behind the singer's visual album. The performance of "[[Flawless (Beyoncé song)|Flawless]]", the second song on the set, opened with the words from [[Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie]]'s [[TED (conference)|TED]] talk projected with big letters on the screen and later Beyoncé performed a choreography with her female dancers similarly to the song's music video.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1722773/beyonce-mrs-carter-tour-details/|title=Beyonce Upgrades Her Mrs. Carter Show Tour: New Songs, Sequins, Surprises|publisher=MTV News|first=Sidney|last=Madden|date=February 21, 2014|accessdate=June 30, 2014}} A performance of "Yoncé" followed with a new choreography with her dancers. "[[Blow (Beyoncé song)|Blow]]" was merged with "Naughty Girl" (2003) and featured a [[burlesque]] and [[disco]]-era theme. During the end of the performance a projection of [[Pac-Man (character)|Pac-Man]], the character of the [[Pac-Man|game with the same name]], eating cherries was projected on an LED screen onstage.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/feb/21/beyonce-live-glasgow-mrs-carter-show-2014|title=Beyoncé – review|work=The Observer|first=Kitty|last=Empire|date=February 21, 2014|accessdate=June 30, 2014}} "Partition" was performed in a similar fashion to its music video with Beyoncé appearing with a silhouette, dancing on a couch in front of a purple light. For "[[Drunk in Love]]", the singer performed a choreographed chair dance. During "[[Haunted (Beyoncé song)|Haunted]]", strobing lights and dancers were present on stage. "Heaven" and "[[XO (song)|XO]]" were performed as the concert's last songs along with "Halo". == Critical reception == [[File:Naughty Girl Beyonce 2013.jpg|thumbnail|left|Beyoncé performing "Naughty Girl" with onstage pyrotechnics.]] Mike Wass from the website [[Idolator (website)|Idolator]] called the show a "concert extravaganza in the style of [[Michael Jackson]] or [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]" praising the fact that the singer made a progress in the production values compared with her previous performances, mostly due to the expensive and high-quality visual projections which "create atmosphere and add another layer to the production". He further praised the singer's "extraordinary talent" during the performances hailing her as "the greatest entertainer of her generation" after seeing the show which showcased "an icon at top of her game".{{cite web|url=http://www.idolator.com/7467592/beyonce-mrs-carter-show-live-review|title=Beyonce Raises The Bar At Staples Center: The Mrs. Carter Show Reviewed|publisher=[[Idolator (website)|Idolator]]|first=Mike|last=Wass|date=June 29, 2013|accessdate=June 29, 2013}} Tiffany Poole from ''[[The Oklahoman]]'' praised the fashion, video backdrops and "some of the most impersonated dance moves on YouTube" concluding, "To say that Beyoncé puts on a good show would be grossly understated."{{cite web|url=http://newsok.com/concert-review-beyonce-brings-her-mrs.-carter-show-to-oklahoma-city/article/3859755|title=Concert review: Beyoncé brings her Mrs. Carter Show to Oklahoma City|work=[[The Oklahoman]]|date=July 6, 2013|accessdate=July 6, 2013}} ''Billboard'' writer Gail Mitchell hailed the concert as a "musical and visual extravaganza" complete with a kaleidoscope of colorful imagery and dancing, which according to him enhanced the music complete with the singer's strong vocals, rather than overshadowing it. He concluded that the tour claimed "the multi-talented artist's intent to join the rarefied ranks of ultimate entertainer".{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1568692/beyonce-shines-on-us-tour-launch-in-la-live-review|title=Beyoncé Shines On U.S. Tour Launch In L.A.: Live Review|work=Billboard|first=Gail|last=Mitchell|date=June 29, 2013|accessdate=June 30, 2014}} Nick Hasted of ''[[The Independent]]'' wrote that the tour followed the stadium trends containing "big-budget movie clips and [[Broadway theatre|Broadway musical]] dance moves, with platoons of backing singers and dancers acting as extras" further hailing it as a "[[Cecil B. DeMille]] spectacle". He finished his reviews by concluding, "what makes this show's largely enervating juggernaut breathe is Beyoncé's tireless physical effort. She has created a literal body of work".{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/reviews/gig-review-behold-beyonc-the-cybernetic-goddess-of-rb-8590792.html|title=Gig review: Behold Beyoncé, the cybernetic goddess of R&B|work=[[The Independent]]|first=Nick|last=Hasted|date=April 26, 2013|accessdate=April 28, 2013}} [[Alexis Petridis]] of ''The Guardian'' who compared the singer's performance with [[Tina Turner]] praised the show's "bombastic" opening and wrote that "there's something powerful and relentless" about it. He concluded "while onstage Beyoncé feels weirdly unassailable".{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/apr/27/beyonce-mrs-carter-review|title=Beyoncé – review|work=The Guardian|date=April 27, 2013|first=Alexis|last=Petridis|authorlink=Alexis Petridis|accessdate=April 28, 2013}} Mikael Wood of ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' noted, "What left the deepest impression was something far more elemental: Beyoncé's ability to make self-aggrandizement seem like an expression of humility... [Her] ambition seemed in proportion with her fans' expectations; she came by the sense of scale honestly." ''The Observer''{{'}}s Kitty Empire highlighted the art direction of the show as "nothing short of breathtaking, making awesome and repeated use of silhouette, of great white blocks of video screens, of live dancers interacting with video". She praised the singer's "fierce" tireless dancing and concluded, "But for all the hauteur here, in couture and bearing, Beyoncé delivers genuine warmth at close range." Bernadette McNulty from ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' found "air of an ancient goddess worship ceremony... [and] of an expensive revue show" in the concert. Although she felt that the choreographies often outshined the music, McNulty concluded: "Yet Beyonce was never less than compelling to watch, and often blistering in her vocal attack". Philip Matusavage of [[musicOMH]] praised Beyoncé's abilities to perform live, calling her "insanely talented" and considered the performance at the B-stage a show highlight; however he commented that the production values of the show, consisting solely of a video screen were "relatively low-key" compared to other pop arena concerts. Matusavage further criticized the repetition of the songs and dance routines which had been previously performed during the singer's other concerts as the tour's "most notable problem".{{cite web|url=http://www.musicomh.com/reviews/live/beyonce-o2-arena-london|title=Beyoncé – O2 Arena, London – Live reviews|work=[[musicOMH]]|first=Philip|last=Matusavage|date=May 4, 2013|accessdate=May 14, 2013}} Shirley Halperin of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' felt that the singer "tore through her... set with the ferocity of a grown woman who has something to prove" and felt that she tried "her damnedest to win the crowd over with an equal dose of sex appeal and good old-fashioned hyping" further showcasing "unequaled showmanship and those killer vocals" which placed her at the top of R&B music. However Halperin criticized the show's set list mainly due to the majority of the songs from the album ''4'', writing, "Bey sounded terrific on all, of course, but with a... ready-to-party audience angling to groove in the aisles, rather than sway with their hands to the heavens, overall it missed the mark." [[Digital Spy]]'s Robert Copsey praised the high-energy nature of the show with vigorous dancing and "blistering" pace but felt that there was a lack of hits performed in the show's first half.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a477446/beyonces-mrs-carter-show-o2-arena-london-live-review.html|title=Beyoncé's 'Mrs Carter Show', O2 Arena London – Live review|work=Digital Spy|first=Robert|last=Copsey|date=April 30, 2013|accessdate=May 10, 2013}} ''NME'' editor Emily Mackay echoed his statements giving a mixed review for the tour, further criticizing the lack of hits in the set list and adding that only a "paucity of material" was incorporated in the set. She further dismissed the placement of interlude films in the show.{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/reviews/beyonce/14407|title=Live Reviews – Beyoncé|work=NME|first=Emily|last=Mackay|date=April 29, 2013|accessdate=June 30, 2014}} A negative review came from ''[[San Jose Mercury News]]''{{'}} Jim Harrington who called the tour "flawed", criticized its set list consisting of "plenty of filler[s]" and the many dissipating costume changes she went through for the show. He further noted that the singer looked and sounded well but blamed the way the show and the production were choreographed.{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/music/ci_23590302/review-beyonce-delivers-flawed-show|title=Review: Beyoncé delivers flawed show|work=[[San Jose Mercury News]]|first=Jim|last=Harrington|date=July 3, 2013|accessdate=June 30, 2014}} [[File:Beyonce Crazy in love 2013.jpg|thumbnail|right|Beyoncé and her background dancers performing a choreography during "Crazy in Love"]] The revamped show in 2014 received acclaim by critics. Isabel Mohan from ''The Daily Telegraph'' acclaimed the revamped show praising the singer's sex appeal and noted that although the set included many new songs, the singer "remained strikingly composed and confident throughout a show which proved her talent, charisma and awe-inspiring thighs".{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/live-music-reviews/10651237/Beyonce-Glasgow-SSE-Hydro-review.html|title=Beyoncé, Glasgow SSE Hydro, review|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|first=Isabel|last=Mohan|date=February 20, 2014|accessdate=February 25, 2014}} Sidney Madden who praised the upgraded set list further commended the show's fashion. Digital Spy's Robert Copsey felt that the show's set list was better than the original one describing the tour as "wall-to-wall amazing Beyoncé". He concluded in his review, "The relentless pace, ever-changing visuals and sheer amount of songs crammed into the set is a lot to take in, let alone the fact that Beyoncé delivers the entire thing with power yet impeccable ease. When it comes to putting on a show of this calibre, these days she's really only competing with herself." ''The Observer''{{'}}s Kitty Empire praised the singer's ranuchiness during the tour different from the other performers and concluded by writing, "There is no question as to Beyoncé's own powers. She can stop and start her all-female band... with a click of her fingers, and keep climbing octaves until you think her lungs are about to jump out of her chest. She sings (with a range that only gets wider and deeper with every tour) and dances (flawlessly) for more than one and a half hours." David Pollock of ''The Independent'' felt that, "this near two-hour epic is a ferocious distillation of musical styles old and new and a stunning declaration of intent that Knowles intends to be recognised as the defining pop artist of her era. It was, at the very least, one of the hardest working shows likely to be witnessed on a stage this year, and with barely a drop of minutely-choreographed sweat to be seen."{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/reviews/beyonce-mrs-carter-show-world-tour-review-9142788.html|title=Beyonce, Mrs Carter Show World Tour, review|work=The Independent|first=David|last=Pollock|date=February 21, 2014|accessdate=June 9, 2014}} The tour received a nomination in the category for Choice Summer Tour at the 2013 Teen Choice Summer Tour losing to [[One Direction]]'s [[Take Me Home Tour (One Direction)|Take Me Home Tour]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1712166/teen-choice-awards-2013-winners.jhtml|title=2013 Teen Choice Similar to the first European leg, a frenzied rush for tickets, further enhanced by the release of the singer's [[Beyoncé (album)|self-titled fifth studio album]] three days before ticket sales began, resulted in extra dates being added for all United Kingdom shows, Dublin, Cologne, Amsterdam and Antwerp.{{cite web|url=http://www.entertainmentwise.com/news/135883/Beyonce-Adds-Extra-Dates-To-2014-UK-Tour-After-Selling-More-Than-550000-Copies-Of-New-Album-In-One-Day|title=Beyonce Adds Extra Dates To 2014 UK Tour After Selling More Than 550,000 Copies Of New Album In One Day|publisher=[[Entertainmentwise]]|first=Alicia|last=Adejobi|date=December 16, 2013|accessdate=December 17, 2013}} For the second European leg, Beyoncé had beaten the record she herself had set earlier in the year, by selling 40,000 tickets in under one hour for the two 2014 concerts at Antwerp.{{cite web|url=https://www.sportpaleis.be/nl/kalender/2013-2014/beyonce|title=Two concerts sold out – Waiting list opens|language=Dutch|work=Sportpaleis Group|date=December 17, 2013|accessdate=December 17, 2013}} ''[[Pollstar]]'' ranked The Mrs. Carter Show at number 2 on its year-end chart of the top twenty grossing worldwide tours with a gross of $188.6 million from the 2013 shows. {{italic title}} [[File:Spofford and Arvin.jpg|thumb|300px|Ned Spofford (William Hite) with Newton Arvin (Keith Phares) in a scene from ''The Scarlet Professor'']] '''''The Scarlet Professor '''''is an [[opera]] by the American composer [[Eric Sawyer]] with [[libretto]] by Harley Erdman, based the biographyWerth, Barry. ''The Scarlet Professor: [[Newton Arvin]]: A Literary Life Shattered by Scandal.''. Random House, 2001. by [[Barry Werth]]. == Performance history == The world premieres of the fully staged opera occurred on September 15–17, 2017, at [[Smith College]] where the events that inspired the performance took place. The opera was performed without intermission with running time of about one hour and 40 minutes. A symposium{{cite web | date = 2017-09-07| title = Singing the Story| work = Grecourt Gate | url = https://www.smith.edu/news/singing-the-story/| accessdate = 2017-10-28 }} on the [[Newton Arvin|Arvin]] case was held all day on September 16. The following weekend the opera was performed with a cast of young artists from the Five Colleges consortium of Western Massachusetts. == Roles == {| class="wikitable" !Role ![[Voice type]] !Premiere cast, 15 September 2017
Conductor: Eduardo Leandro |- | [[Newton Arvin]] ||[[tenor]]|| William Hite |- | Ned Spofford ||[[baritone]]|| Keith Phares |- | [[Hester Prynne]] ||[[mezzo-soprano]]|| Blythe Gaissert |- | Helen Bacon ||[[soprano]]|| Sarah Pelletier |- | [[Truman Capote]] ||[[countertenor]]|| Bryan Pollock |- | Officer Regan|| baritone|| James Dernier |- | Doctor || soprano || Kristen Watson |- | Arthur Summerfield || baritone || Sumner Thompson |} == Instrumentation == The 9-piece instrumental ensemble consisted of piano, percussion, flute, clarinet, tenor saxophone, and strings, with both electric and double bass. == Reception == Reviewer Marvin J. Ward found the opera a "compelling and captivating work", adding "...composer Eric Sawyer has a penchant for choosing historical events, especially local ones, as the subjects of his operas. This is the third that I have seen, each more polished and refined than its predecessor, with ''The Scarlet Professor'' scoring a 10/10 in my book."{{cite web | date = 2017-09-21| first=Marvin | last=Ward| title = ''Scarlet Professor'' Recalls Gay 'Smut' Target As Opera| work = Classical Voice North America | url = {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} The '''Théâtre des Variétés-Amusantes''' was a theatre in Paris.
==History== In 1778, Louis Lécluse (or Lécluze), a former actor at the [[Théâtre national de l'Opéra-Comique|Opéra-Comique]] turned dentist, opened a theatre at [[théâtre de la foire|foire Saint-Laurent]], which shortly afterwards he transferred to the [[boulevard du Temple]], at the corner of rue de Lancry and rue de Bondy (now rue René-Boulanger, [[Paris Xe arrondissement|Xe arrondissement]]).
Unable to bear the hostility this new enterprise generated, Lécluse ceded his theatre and its company to three former dancers of the [[Opéra national de Paris|Opéra]] – Fierville fils, [[François Duval (dancer)|Malter]] and [[Hamoir (dancer)|Hamoir]] – as well as the financier Lemercier. The theatre opened on 12 April 1779 and it attracted large audiences by its varied and well-performed repertoire. [[Dorvigny]] wrote several plays for it, including ''Janot ou les Battus paient l'amende'' (11 June 1779), which was a great success.
In 1784, the theatre's directors had their privilege revoked by a Conseil d'État decree, in favour of Gaillard and Dorfeuille, after a complaint from the [[Opéra national de Paris|Académie royale de Musique]]. The new directors moved the theatre to the [[Palais-Royal]] and opened their new building on 1 January 1785, under the name '''Variétés du Palais-Royal'''. Its fare until that date had been farces, which they replaced with comedies, welcoming [[Jacques Marie Boutet|Monvel]] and [[Julie Candeille]], then [[François-Joseph Talma|Talma]], [[Dugazon]] and [[Rose Vestris|Mme Vestris]]. From then on the theatre was renamed the ''Théâtre-Français de la rue Richelieu'', then the ''[[Comédie-Française|Théâtre de la République]]''.

The following is a '''timeline of the governorship of [[Ezenwo Nyesom Wike]]''', also known as the '''Wike administration''', from his [[Inauguration of Ezenwo Nyesom Wike|inauguration]] as [[Governor of Rivers State]] on 29 May 2015 to present.
==2015== ===May – August=== *'''29 May''' – Wike sworn in as 6th [[Governor of Rivers State]]; delivers speech. As first moves, Governor Wike appoints acting [[Chief Judge of Rivers State|Chief Judge]], [[Rivers State Customary Court of Appeal|Customary Court of Appeal President]], directs state courts to resume work and reinstates fired lecturers of the [[Rivers State University of Science and Technology|University of Science and Technology]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Rivers: Wike Takes Over …Vows To Fight Insecurity, Promote Business|url=http://www.thetidenewsonline.com/2015/05/29/rivers-wike-takes-over-vows-to-fight-insecurity-promote-business/|accessdate=21 June 2015|work=[[The Tide (Nigeria)|The Tide]]|date=29 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Wike reinstates sacked lecturers, appoints Chief Judge|url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2015/05/wike-reinstates-sacked-lecturers-appoints-chief-judge/|accessdate=21 June 2015|work=Vanguard|date=29 May 2015}}</ref> *'''30 May''' – Image surfaces online of Governor Wike and family. *'''31 May''' – Thanksgiving service for Governor Wike takes place. The Governor reveals that past administration had vandalized the [[Government House, Port Harcourt|Government House]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Vandalism of Rivers State Government House: Wike says it may take three months for him to operate from the facility|url=http://scannewsnigeria.com/featured-post/vandalism-of-rivers-state-government-house-wike-says-it-may-take-three-months-for-him-to-operate-from-the-facility/|accessdate=21 June 2015|work=ScanNews Nigeria|date=31 May 2015}}</ref>
*'''1 June''' – Governor Wike issues financial independence declaration for the [[Rivers State Judiciary|Judiciary]], inaugurates [[8th Rivers State House of Assembly]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Nengia|first1=Kevin|title=Wike Swears-In Rivers Acting CJ …Proclaims 8th Assembly, Today …Promises Cabinet Of Rivers’ Best|url=http://www.thetidenewsonline.com/2015/06/01/wike-swears-in-rivers-acting-cj-proclaims-8th-assembly-today-promises-cabinet-of-rivers-best/|accessdate=21 June 2015|work=[[The Tide (Nigeria)|The Tide]]|date=1 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="june 1">{{cite news|title=Wike Declares Financial Autonomy for Rivers Judiciary|url=http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/wike-declares-financial-autonomy-for-rivers-judiciary/210910/|accessdate=21 June 2015|work=Thisday|date=2 June 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150621171021/http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/wike-declares-financial-autonomy-for-rivers-judiciary/210910/|archivedate=21 June 2015|df=}}</ref> *'''2 June''' – Governor Wike announces plans to complete the University of Science and Technology Law Faculty building. He summons all Permanent Secretaries to give account on past expenditure.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Nengia|first1=Kevin|title=Wike Demands Financial Record From Perm Secs …Orders Banks Not To Grant Loans To LGCs, MDAs|url=http://www.thetidenewsonline.com/2015/06/03/wike-demands-financial-record-from-perm-secs-orders-banks-not-to-grant-loans-to-lgcs-mdas/|accessdate=21 June 2015|work=[[The Tide (Nigeria)|The Tide]]|date=3 June 2015}}</ref> *'''5 June''' – [[Kenneth Kobani]] is appointed [[Secretary to the State Government]] while [[Chukwuemeka Woke]] is made [[Rivers State Chief of Staff|Chief of Staff]]. [[Felix A. Obuah]], Chairman of the [[Rivers State People's Democratic Party]] takes over [[Rivers State Waste Management Agency|Waste Management Agency]]. The Governor's appointments of four commissioners and seven special advisers get confirmed by the House.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Godwin|first1=Ann|title=Rivers House confirms four commissioners, others|url=http://www.ngrguardiannews.com/2015/06/rivers-house-confirms-four-commissioners-others/|accessdate=26 June 2015|work=The Guardian|date=5 June 2015|location=Port Harcourt}}</ref> *'''8 June''' – Governor Wike receives authorization from the Rivers State House of Assembly to dismiss all members of the [[Rivers State Independent Electoral Commission|Independent Electoral Commission]] and [[Rivers State Judicial Service Commission|Judicial Service Commission]].<ref name=leadership1/> *'''11 June''' – The Rivers State House of Assembly grants Governor Wike's request to borrow ₦10 billion (approximately US$50,276,600) to finance vital development projects in the state.<ref name=leadership1>{{cite news|last1=Onukwugha|first1=Anayo|title=Wike’s Many Challenges|url=http://leadership.ng/news/440552/rivers-wikes-many-challenges|accessdate=21 June 2015|work=Leadership|date=15 June 2015}}</ref> Governor Wike also expresses commitment to halt multiple taxation. *'''12 June''' – Governor Wike administers the Oath of Office to his first set of appointees. They include Kenneth Kobani, Secretary to the State Government, Chukwuemeka Woke, Chief of Staff, [[Emmanuel C. Aguma]], [[Attorney General of Rivers State|Attorney General]] and [[Fred Kpakol]], [[Rivers State Ministry of Finance|Finance Commissioner]]. Others are [[Emmanuel Okah]], Housing Commissioner, [[Onimim Jacks]], [[Rivers State Ministry of Agriculture|Agriculture Commissioner]], and Sir. Opunabo Inko-Tariah, Media and Publicity Special Adviser.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Naku|first1=Dennis|title=WIke swears in Rivers SSG, 4 Commissioners, others|url=http://nationalmirroronline.net/new/wike-swears-in-rivers-ssg-4-commissioners-others/|accessdate=26 June 2015|work=National Mirror|date=13 June 2015}}</ref> *'''15 June''' – Governor Wike dissolves all boards of parastatals and agencies with the exception of the Rivers State Waste Management Agency and the [[Greater Port Harcourt City Development Authority]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Wike Dissolves Boards, Parastatals|url=http://leadership.ng/news/440668/wike-dissolves-boards-parastatals|accessdate=21 June 2015|work=Leadership|date=15 June 2015}}</ref> Road [[Government contractor|contractors]] in Port Harcourt receive directives from the Governor to return to site and complete all abandoned projects.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ugwuanyi|first1=Theresa|title=Wike orders resumption of work on abandoned projects in Rivers State|url=http://www.mothertessie.com/2015/06/wike-orders-resumption-of-work-on.html|accessdate=28 June 2015|work=Mothertessie|date=16 June 2015}}</ref> *'''17 June''' – Governor Wike issues an order demanding immediate dismissal of 344 staff members, including lecturers of the [[Rivers State Polytechnic]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Onukwugha|first1=Anayo|title=Wike Sacks 344 Staff Of State Polytechnic|url=http://leadership.ng/news/441182/wike-sacks-344-staff-of-state-polytechnic|accessdate=21 June 2015|work=Leadership|date=17 June 2015}}</ref> *'''19 June''' – Governor Wike appoints a Judicial Commission of Inquiry under the chairmanship of Justice George Omereji to inquire into the sale of valued assets and funds withdrawal by the preceding administration of [[Chibuike Amaechi]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ebiri|first1=Kelvin|title=Wike Sets Up Commission To Probe Amaechi’s Sales Of Rivers State’s Assets|url=http://www.ngrguardiannews.com/2015/06/wike-sets-up-commission-to-probe-amaechis-sales-of-rivers-assets/|accessdate=21 June 2015|work=The Guardian|date=20 June 2015|location=Port He pledges to give the facilities the boost they need to function efficiently.<ref>{{cite news|title=RSG To Rehabilitate Bori, Emohua Hospitals|url=http://www.thetidenewsonline.com/2015/06/29/rsg-to-rehabilitate-bori-emohua-hospitals/|accessdate=29 June 2015|work=[[The Tide (Nigeria)|The Tide]]|date=29 June 2015}}</ref> The managements of [[Dolphins F.C. (Port Harcourt)|Dolphins F.C.]] and [[Sharks F.C.]] laud the Governor for clearing all outstanding salaries owed the clubs. *'''28 June''' – Governor Wike announces plans for amendments to the Rivers law|url=http://scannewsnigeria.com/news/rivers-state-to-establish-stronger-anti-kidnapping-law/|accessdate=29 June 2015|work=ScanNews|date=28 June 2015}}</ref> Senator [[George Sekibo]], members of late Eze Ambrose Adele, Nyenweli Oropotoma|url=http://scannewsnigeria.com/news/wike-condoles-with-family-of-late-eze-ambrose-adele-nyenweli-oropotoma/|accessdate=29 June 2015|work=ScanNews|date=28 Wike.<ref>{{cite news|title=Wike commends corps members for positive roles they played in the success of 2015 elections|url=http://scannewsnigeria.com/news/wike-commends-corps-members-for-positive-roles-they-played-in-the-success-of-2015-elections-3/|accessdate=29 June 2015|work=ScanNews|date=29 June 2015}}</ref> *'''30 June''' – The Governor tours the facilities of Indorama Eleme Petrochemicals Ltd. in Port Harcourt to endorse the Fertilizer Plant project.<ref>{{cite news|title=Wike to develop a framework to attract international and local investors to Rivers State|url=http://scannewsnigeria.com/featured-post/wike-to-develop-a-framework-to-attract-international-and-local-investors-to-rivers-state/|accessdate=30 June 2015|work=ScanNews|date=30 June 2015}}</ref> Rivers State House of Assembly approves additional ₦20 billion (approximately US$100,553,200) loan for road maintenance as well as construction.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Chinwo|first1=Ernest|title=Again, Rivers Assembly Authorises Wike to Take N20bn Loan|url=http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/again-rivers-assembly-authorises-wike-to-take-n20bn-loan/213490/|accessdate=1 July 2015|work=Thisday Live|date=30 June 2015|location=Port Ezike]] over security.<ref>{{cite news|title=Don’t Politicise Crime Fighting, Wike Charges New Rivers State CP|url=https://www.informationng.com/2015/07/dont-politicise-crime-fighting-wike-charges-new-rivers-cp.html|accessdate=4 July 2015|work=Information Nigeria|date=4 July 2015}}</ref> *'''4 July''' – 2015}}</ref> *'''11 July''' – Governor Wike unveils initiative aimed at reconstructing a portion of the East West Road connecting [[Onne|Onne seaport]] using the expertise of Reynolds Construction Company (RCC) in partnership with the federal government and port stakeholders.<ref>{{cite news|title=Wike initiates repairs of Federal road to Onne Sea Port, gets commitment from critical stakeholders|url=http://scannewsnigeria.com/news/wike-initiates-repairs-of-federal-road-to-onne-sea-port-gets-commitment-from-critical-stakeholders/|accessdate=11 July 2015|work=ScanNews|date=11 July Ibani]] attend a special [[France|French]] [[national day]] event.<ref>{{cite news|title=Wike to French Authorities: Continue to support the fight against Boko Haram|url=http://scannewsnigeria.com/featured-post/wike-to-french-authorities-continue-to-support-the-fight-against-boko-hara/|accessdate=12 July 2015|work=ScanNews|date=12 July 2015}}</ref> *'''12 July''' – The Governor embarks on inspection of roads, the Faculty of Law Building project and charges contractors at work to deliver on schedule. Governor Wike also meets with the Executive Board of the Oil and Gas Free Zone at the Brick House.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Akasike|first1=Chukwudi|title=Why we’re working on East-West road –
